batch.name: Campbell Ch5 Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules — Olympiad Expansion

questions.question: The four major classes of biological macromolecules are carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Which statement correctly distinguishes lipids from the other three?
options: Lipids are the only macromolecules that contain carbon
Lipids are the largest of all biological macromolecules

Lipids are not true polymers — they are not assembled from repeating monomer subunits by condensation reactions in the same way as polysaccharides, proteins, and nucleic acids, but rather are grouped by their hydrophobic character
Lipids are the only macromolecules that are soluble in water
questions.explanation: Unlike carbohydrates (polymers of monosaccharides), proteins (polymers of amino acids), and nucleic acids (polymers of nucleotides), lipids are a chemically diverse group defined by their hydrophobic nature rather than by a common monomeric structure. While fats are built from glycerol and fatty acids, these components are not identical repeating units. Phospholipids, steroids, and waxes have very different structures. The unifying feature is hydrophobicity (low water solubility). Option A is wrong because all macromolecules contain carbon. Option B is wrong because proteins and nucleic acids are typically much larger. Option D is wrong because lipids are hydrophobic and poorly soluble in water.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Alpha (α) and beta (β) glycosidic linkages in polysaccharides produce dramatically different biological properties because:
options: α-linkages produce straight chains while β-linkages produce branched chains

α-1,4 linkages in starch create helical coils that are easily hydrolyzed by amylase, while β-1,4 linkages in cellulose create straight, rigid chains stabilized by interchain hydrogen bonds that form microfibrils resistant to most animal digestive enzymes
β-linkages are always weaker than α-linkages and break spontaneously
Both linkages produce identical three-dimensional structures with different names
questions.explanation: The stereochemistry of the glycosidic bond (α vs β at the anomeric carbon) has profound structural consequences. In starch (amylose), α-1,4 glycosidic bonds place each glucose rotated ~60° relative to the next, creating a helical coil. This structure is readily accessible to α-amylase and other digestive enzymes. In cellulose, β-1,4 bonds flip alternating glucose residues 180°, creating straight, extended chains. Adjacent chains form extensive interchain hydrogen bonds, assembling into rigid microfibrils with tensile strength comparable to steel. Most animals lack cellulase enzymes to hydrolyze β-1,4 bonds — only symbionts (termite gut bacteria, ruminant microflora) can digest cellulose. This single stereochemical difference (α vs β at C-1) determines whether a polysaccharide serves as energy storage (starch, glycogen) or structural support (cellulose, chitin). Option A is wrong — branching depends on α-1,6 linkages. Option C is wrong — both have similar bond energies. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Phospholipid bilayer self-assembly is driven by the hydrophobic effect. If you add purified phospholipids to an aqueous solution, they will spontaneously form bilayer vesicles (liposomes) because:
options: This arrangement maximizes the total energy of the system
Covalent bonds form between adjacent phospholipid molecules in the bilayer

The bilayer structure minimizes the thermodynamically unfavorable contact between hydrophobic fatty acid tails and water, while hydrophilic head groups interact favorably with the aqueous phase — the resulting increase in entropy of released clathrate water molecules drives the process
An external energy source (ATP) is required to form the bilayer
questions.explanation: Phospholipid bilayer self-assembly is a spontaneous process driven by the hydrophobic effect. When amphipathic phospholipids are added to water, their hydrophobic tails disrupt water's hydrogen bonding network, forcing water molecules into highly ordered 'clathrate' structures. Bilayer formation buries the hydrophobic tails away from water, releasing these ordered water molecules and increasing their entropy — this entropic gain is the primary thermodynamic driving force (TΔS term). The hydrophilic head groups face the aqueous phase, forming favorable electrostatic and hydrogen bonding interactions. The process is spontaneous (negative ΔG) and requires no energy input. The resulting liposomes are thermodynamically stable and kinetically accessible. Option A is wrong because it minimizes free energy, not maximizes total energy. Option B is wrong because no covalent bonds form between lipids. Option D is wrong because no ATP is needed.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The primary structure of a protein determines its three-dimensional shape through the process of folding. Anfinsen's classic ribonuclease experiment demonstrated this by showing that:
options: Proteins fold randomly into different shapes each time they are synthesized

Denatured and reduced ribonuclease A, when the denaturant is removed and disulfide bonds are allowed to re-form under oxidizing conditions, spontaneously refolds into its native conformation with full enzymatic activity — proving that all information needed for folding is contained in the amino acid sequence
Protein folding requires a template from the parent protein
Ribonuclease cannot refold after denaturation under any conditions
questions.explanation: Christian Anfinsen's 1972 Nobel Prize-winning experiment with ribonuclease A (RNase A, 124 amino acids, 4 disulfide bonds) provided definitive evidence that the amino acid sequence contains all information necessary for protein folding. He denatured RNase A with urea (breaking non-covalent interactions) and β-mercaptoethanol (reducing the 4 disulfide bonds), destroying enzymatic activity. When he removed both agents and allowed the protein to refold in an oxidizing environment, the protein spontaneously recovered ~100% of its native enzymatic activity — meaning it found the one correct native fold out of 10^39 possible random configurations. When he removed urea first but kept the disulfide bonds scrambled, only ~1% activity was recovered, but addition of trace β-mercaptoethanol (allowing disulfide reshuffling) restored full activity. Option A contradicts the experimental result. Option C describes a prion-like model. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The Watson-Crick base pairing rules (A-T, G-C) in DNA are maintained by:
options: Covalent bonds between complementary bases across the double helix
Hydrophobic interactions between the sugar-phosphate backbones

Hydrogen bonds between complementary bases (A-T: 2 hydrogen bonds; G-C: 3 hydrogen bonds) combined with geometric complementarity that ensures a purine always pairs with a pyrimidine, maintaining the uniform 2 nm diameter of the double helix
Ionic bonds between the negatively charged bases
questions.explanation: Watson-Crick base pairing involves specific hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs: adenine forms 2 hydrogen bonds with thymine (or uracil in RNA), and guanine forms 3 hydrogen bonds with cytosine. Beyond hydrogen bonding, the pairing rules are enforced by geometric (steric) complementarity: the double helix has a uniform diameter of 2 nm (20 Å) because a purine (two-ring, ~1.2 nm wide) always pairs with a pyrimidine (one-ring, ~0.8 nm wide). A purine-purine pair would be too wide, and a pyrimidine-pyrimidine pair too narrow. The additional G-C hydrogen bond makes GC-rich regions more thermally stable (higher melting temperature). Base stacking interactions (van der Waals and hydrophobic) between adjacent base pairs also contribute significantly to duplex stability. Option A is wrong — base pairing uses non-covalent hydrogen bonds. Option B is wrong — backbone interactions don't determine base pairing specificity. Option D is wrong — bases are not ionic.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Saturated fatty acids differ from unsaturated fatty acids in their effect on membrane fluidity because:
options: Saturated fatty acids contain double bonds that introduce kinks, increasing fluidity

Unsaturated fatty acids have cis double bonds that create bends in the hydrocarbon chain, preventing tight packing and increasing fluidity, while saturated fatty acids lack double bonds and pack tightly through extensive van der Waals interactions, decreasing fluidity
Both types of fatty acids have identical effects on membrane properties
Saturated fatty acids are always shorter than unsaturated ones, making membranes thinner
questions.explanation: Saturated fatty acids have no C=C double bonds, allowing their hydrocarbon chains to adopt an extended, all-trans conformation that packs tightly with neighboring chains through extensive van der Waals (London dispersion) interactions. This tight packing creates ordered, rigid membranes with higher melting points. Unsaturated fatty acids contain one or more cis C=C double bonds, each introducing a ~30° bend that disrupts the regular packing arrangement. This prevents neighboring chains from aligning closely, creating more space and disorder — increasing membrane fluidity. At physiological temperatures, a higher ratio of unsaturated to saturated fatty acids increases fluidity. Organisms regulate membrane fluidity through fatty acid desaturases and by incorporating cholesterol (which moderates fluidity in both directions). Option A reverses the structures. Option C is wrong — their effects are opposite. Option D is an incorrect generalization.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Levinthal's paradox highlights a fundamental puzzle in protein folding. The paradox states that:
options: If a protein explored all possible conformations randomly (sampling one per picosecond), a 100-residue protein would require ~10^87 years — yet real proteins fold in milliseconds to seconds, indicating that folding follows a directed pathway through a funnel-shaped energy landscape rather than a random search
Proteins fold too slowly to be useful in biological systems
All proteins fold into the same shape regardless of their amino acid sequence
Protein folding violates the second law of thermodynamics
questions.explanation: Cyrus Levinthal calculated that a protein of 100 residues, with each residue having approximately 3 possible backbone conformations (φ, ψ angles), would have ~3^100 ≈ 5 × 10^47 possible conformations. Sampling each for 10^-13 seconds (molecular vibration timescale) would require ~5 × 10^34 seconds (>10^27 years) — far longer than the age of the universe. Yet proteins fold in microseconds to seconds. This paradox implies that proteins do NOT search conformational space randomly. Modern understanding views folding as descent through a funnel-shaped energy landscape: local interactions form rapidly (secondary structure nucleation), guiding the protein toward progressively lower energy states through a limited set of pathways. Hydrophobic collapse, nucleation-condensation, and framework models all describe aspects of this directed process. Option B is the opposite — proteins fold remarkably fast. Option C contradicts amino acid sequence specificity. Option D is wrong — folding doesn't violate thermodynamics.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Glycogen and amylopectin are both branched storage polysaccharides of glucose. Glycogen is more highly branched than amylopectin because:
options: Glycogen uses β-1,4 linkages while amylopectin uses α-1,4 linkages

Glycogen has branch points (α-1,6 linkages) every 8-12 glucose residues, while amylopectin branches every 24-30 residues — the more frequent branching creates more non-reducing ends for simultaneous glycogen phosphorylase action, enabling rapid glucose mobilization during exercise
Glycogen contains fructose monomers while amylopectin contains glucose
Both have identical branching patterns and are functionally interchangeable
questions.explanation: Both glycogen and amylopectin use α-1,4 glycosidic bonds for the main chain and α-1,6 bonds at branch points. The key difference is branching frequency: glycogen branches every 8-12 glucose residues, while amylopectin branches every 24-30 residues. This means glycogen is much more highly branched, creating a dense, spherical molecule (glycogen granules, 10-40 nm diameter) with numerous non-reducing ends. Each non-reducing end is a substrate for glycogen phosphorylase, so a single glycogen granule can be simultaneously attacked by many phosphorylase enzymes, enabling extremely rapid glucose mobilization (essential during intense exercise or fight-or-flight response). Glycogen is found in animal liver and muscle, while amylopectin is found in plants alongside amylose (linear). Option A is wrong — both use α-1,4 linkages. Option C is wrong — both contain glucose. Option D is wrong — they differ in branching frequency.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Cholesterol's role in cell membrane structure is paradoxical because it both increases and decreases membrane fluidity depending on temperature. This is because:
options: Cholesterol is equally distributed between both membrane leaflets and has no effect on fluidity
Cholesterol makes membranes more permeable to all solutes at all temperatures
Cholesterol only affects the outer leaflet of the membrane, not the inner leaflet

At physiological temperatures (37°C), cholesterol's rigid steroid ring system restricts phospholipid movement, reducing fluidity; at low temperatures, cholesterol disrupts tight packing of saturated fatty acid chains, preventing the membrane from solidifying — thus cholesterol acts as a 'fluidity buffer'
questions.explanation: Cholesterol's amphipathic structure (small polar hydroxyl head, rigid 4-ring steroid body, flexible hydrocarbon tail) allows it to intercalate between phospholipids. At normal body temperature (37°C), the rigid steroid rings restrict the motion of the immediately adjacent phospholipid acyl chains, reducing membrane fluidity and making the membrane less permeable to small water-soluble molecules. At low temperatures, when saturated phospholipids would otherwise pack tightly into an ordered gel phase, cholesterol's bulky ring system physically disrupts this regular packing, preventing solidification and maintaining some fluidity. This dual action makes cholesterol a 'fluidity buffer' that maintains membrane properties across a range of temperatures. Cholesterol also increases membrane mechanical strength and reduces permeability to ions and polar molecules. Cholesterol comprises ~25-50% of membrane lipids in animal cells. Option A is wrong. Option C is wrong — cholesterol is found in both leaflets. Option B oversimplifies.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The alpha helix, a common protein secondary structure element, is stabilized by:
options: Covalent bonds between amino acid side chains
Hydrophobic interactions between the backbone carbonyl oxygens
Hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen (C=O) of residue i and the amide hydrogen (N-H) of residue i+4 along the backbone, resulting in 3.6 residues per helical turn with a pitch of 5.4 Å
Ionic bonds between alternating positive and negative charges on the backbone
questions.explanation: The α-helix is a right-handed helical structure stabilized by hydrogen bonds between backbone atoms: specifically, the C=O of amino acid i acts as a hydrogen bond acceptor, and the N-H of amino acid i+4 acts as a donor. This i→i+4 pattern creates 3.6 residues per turn, with a rise of 1.5 Å per residue and a pitch (distance per complete turn) of 5.4 Å. The helix has a dipole moment (N-terminus positive, C-terminus negative) due to the aligned C=O groups. Side chains project outward from the helix axis, and their properties determine helix-helix packing (hydrophobic residues in membrane helices, amphipathic helices at protein surfaces). Certain residues are helix-breakers: proline (rigid ring disrupts backbone geometry) and glycine (too flexible, entropically unfavorable). Option A describes tertiary structure interactions. Option B misidentifies the bonding. Option D is wrong — the backbone is not charged.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Sickle cell disease is caused by a single amino acid substitution (Glu6Val) in β-globin. This mutation causes hemoglobin S to polymerize under deoxygenated conditions because:
options: The substitution of hydrophilic glutamate (charged, polar) with hydrophobic valine creates a 'sticky' hydrophobic patch on the surface of deoxyhemoglobin S that fits into a complementary hydrophobic pocket on an adjacent HbS molecule, driving fiber polymerization
Valine is larger than glutamate, making the protein unfold completely
Valine forms extra disulfide bonds that cross-link hemoglobin molecules
The mutation changes the protein from α-helical to entirely β-sheet structure
questions.explanation: In normal hemoglobin A, position 6 of β-globin has glutamate (Glu), a negatively charged, hydrophilic residue on the protein surface. In hemoglobin S (HbS), this is replaced by valine (Val), a hydrophobic residue. In the deoxygenated (T-state) conformation, this Val6 residue is exposed on the surface and creates a hydrophobic 'knob' that inserts into a hydrophobic pocket (formed by Phe85 and Leu88) on an adjacent HbS molecule. This intermolecular interaction drives the formation of long, stiff fibers (14 HbS strands twisted into a rope-like polymer). These fibers distort the red blood cell into the characteristic sickle shape, causing vaso-occlusion, hemolysis, and tissue ischemia. In oxyhemoglobin (R-state), conformational changes hide the complementary pocket, preventing polymerization — explaining why sickling occurs only under low O₂ conditions. Option B is wrong about size. Option C is wrong — Val cannot form disulfide bonds. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The Chargaff rules for DNA state that the amount of adenine equals thymine (A=T) and guanine equals cytosine (G=C). However, in single-stranded RNA:
options: The Chargaff rules still apply exactly because RNA has the same base pairing
RNA has double the amount of each base compared to DNA
RNA contains no purines, so the rules are irrelevant

A does NOT necessarily equal U, and G does NOT necessarily equal C, because RNA is typically single-stranded and does not have a complementary strand to enforce base pairing ratios across the entire molecule
questions.explanation: Chargaff's rules (%A = %T, %G = %C) are a direct consequence of Watson-Crick base pairing in double-stranded DNA: every A on one strand is paired with T on the complementary strand. In single-stranded RNA, there is no complementary strand to enforce these ratios across the entire molecule. The base composition of RNA reflects the sequence of the gene from which it was transcribed, which may have any ratio of bases. However, within RNA's intramolecular secondary structures (hairpins, stem-loops, pseudoknots), locally base-paired regions do follow Chargaff-like rules (A=U, G=C in those segments). Transfer RNA (tRNA), ribosomal RNA (rRNA), and messenger RNA (mRNA) all have regions of intramolecular base pairing. Option A is wrong because ssRNA is not constrained by complementary pairing across the molecule. Option C is wrong — RNA contains purines. Option B is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Cellulose is the most abundant organic compound on Earth, yet most animals cannot digest it. The evolutionary advantage of cellulase-producing symbionts in herbivores is that:
options: Cellulase converts cellulose directly into glucose, which is then absorbed and oxidized for ATP — this gives herbivores access to a virtually unlimited energy source in plant cell walls that is inaccessible to non-symbiont-containing animals
Symbionts produce vitamins but do not help with cellulose digestion
All animals can digest cellulose without symbionts
Cellulase only breaks down lignin, not cellulose
questions.explanation: Cellulose (β-1,4-linked glucose polymer) constitutes 30-50% of plant dry weight and represents an enormous energy reservoir. The β-glycosidic bonds cannot be hydrolyzed by any vertebrate enzyme. However, certain bacteria, protists, and fungi produce cellulases (β-1,4-glucosidases) that cleave these bonds, releasing glucose monomers. In ruminants (cows, sheep), cellulolytic microorganisms in the rumen ferment cellulose to volatile fatty acids (VFAs: acetate, propionate, butyrate), which are absorbed and used as the primary energy source (~70% of energy). In termites, flagellated protists (Trichonympha) and bacteria in the hindgut digest cellulose. Rabbits and horses use hindgut fermentation. This symbiosis was a transformative evolutionary innovation that opened plant cell wall biomass as a food source. Option B underestimates the role. Option C is wrong. Option D confuses cellulose with lignin.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Chaperone proteins (e.g., GroEL/GroES in bacteria, Hsp70/Hsp90 in eukaryotes) assist protein folding by:
options: Providing information about the correct final structure that is not contained in the amino acid sequence
Catalyzing the formation of peptide bonds during translation

Creating an isolated environment that prevents aggregation of hydrophobic surfaces on partially folded proteins, giving the polypeptide multiple rounds of folding attempts without interference from neighboring proteins — without changing the thermodynamic endpoint of folding
Converting proteins from α-helices to β-sheets
questions.explanation: Molecular chaperones do NOT provide structural information or determine the final folded state — they facilitate the self-assembly process encoded in the amino acid sequence. The GroEL/GroES (Hsp60) system in bacteria works as follows: (1) An unfolded or misfolded polypeptide binds to the hydrophobic interior of the GroEL ring (apical domains); (2) GroES caps the ring, creating an isolated chamber that is now hydrophilic; (3) Inside this 'Anfinsen cage,' the protein attempts to fold without the risk of aggregating with other hydrophobic proteins; (4) After ~10 seconds, ATP hydrolysis triggers GroES release and substrate ejection. If the protein is not yet folded, it can rebind for another round. Hsp70 chaperones work differently, binding and releasing short hydrophobic segments to prevent premature aggregation. Chaperones reduce the kinetic barriers to folding without altering the thermodynamic minimum. Option A is wrong per Anfinsen's principle. Option B describes ribosomes. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Trans fats (partially hydrogenated vegetable oils) increase cardiovascular disease risk because:
options: They are directly toxic to heart muscle cells at any concentration
They are metabolized too quickly, causing energy surges that damage blood vessels
They are identical to unsaturated fats and have no unique health effects

They raise LDL cholesterol and lower HDL cholesterol, promote endothelial dysfunction, increase systemic inflammation, and their straight-chain geometry (similar to saturated fats) increases membrane rigidity in arterial walls
questions.explanation: Trans fatty acids produced by industrial partial hydrogenation have a trans configuration around the remaining double bonds, giving them a relatively straight chain geometry similar to saturated fats. This straight geometry allows tight packing in cell membranes, increasing rigidity. Trans fats affect cardiovascular health through multiple mechanisms: (1) They increase plasma LDL ('bad' cholesterol) levels by upregulating hepatic CETP activity and decreasing LDL receptor expression; (2) They decrease HDL ('good' cholesterol); (3) They promote endothelial dysfunction by reducing nitric oxide production; (4) They increase inflammatory markers (IL-6, TNF-α, CRP); (5) They may promote insulin resistance. A meta-analysis estimated that a 2% increase in trans fat calories was associated with a 23% increased risk of coronary heart disease. The WHO has called for global elimination of industrial trans fats by 2023. Option A is an overstatement. Option C is wrong. Option B is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The peptide bond has which specific geometric property that is critical for protein structure?
options: Complete rotational freedom around both the C-N bond and the Cα-C bond
A tetrahedral geometry at the nitrogen atom, allowing flexible rotation

Planarity — the six atoms (Cα, C, O, N, H, Cα) are coplanar due to partial double bond character of the C-N bond, with the trans configuration favored in >99.9% of peptide bonds (except before proline, where ~5% adopt cis)
A completely rigid structure with no movement possible at any backbone bond
questions.explanation: The peptide bond exhibits partial double bond character due to resonance delocalization of the nitrogen lone pair into the carbonyl. This restricts rotation around the C-N bond, forcing the peptide group (O=C-NH) and the flanking α-carbons into a plane. The six atoms Cα(i)-C(i)-O(i)-N(i+1)-H(i+1)-Cα(i+1) are essentially coplanar. The trans configuration (flanking Cα atoms on opposite sides) is strongly favored (99.95%) because the cis configuration has steric clash between the side chains. The exception is X-Pro bonds, where the cis isomer is found in ~5% of cases because proline's cyclic side chain reduces the energy difference between cis and trans. While the peptide bond itself is rigid, the backbone retains flexibility through rotation around the N-Cα bond (φ angle) and Cα-C bond (ψ angle), constrained by Ramachandran limits. Option A is wrong — C-N rotation is restricted. Option B is wrong — nitrogen is sp2, not tetrahedral. Option D overstates rigidity.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The melting temperature (Tm) of DNA is directly related to its GC content because:
options: G-C base pairs have three hydrogen bonds (vs two for A-T), and GC-rich regions have stronger base stacking interactions, requiring more thermal energy to denature
A-T base pairs are covalently linked while G-C pairs use only hydrogen bonds
GC content does not affect Tm; only DNA length matters
G-C base pairs are held together by hydrophobic interactions that are unaffected by temperature
questions.explanation: DNA melting temperature (Tm, the temperature at which 50% of the double helix is denatured to single strands) increases linearly with GC content. The empirical relationship is approximately Tm = 69.3 + 0.41(%GC) for long DNA in standard salt conditions. G-C base pairs contribute more to duplex stability than A-T pairs for two reasons: (1) G-C pairs have 3 hydrogen bonds (estimated ~13 kJ/mol) versus 2 for A-T pairs (~8 kJ/mol); (2) GC-rich sequences have stronger base stacking interactions (π-π stacking) because guanine and cytosine have larger dipole moments and more favorable overlap geometry. For E. coli DNA (51% GC), Tm ≈ 90.5°C; for Mycobacterium tuberculosis (65% GC), Tm is higher; for AT-rich organisms like Plasmodium falciparum (19% GC), Tm is lower. This principle is used in PCR primer design and hybridization experiments. Option B is wrong — no base pairs are covalent. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids are classified as essential fatty acids because:
options: They can be synthesized by all mammalian cells from acetyl-CoA
They are not essential; the term is a misnomer

Humans lack the desaturase enzymes needed to introduce double bonds beyond carbon 9 from the carboxyl end, so α-linolenic acid (18:3, ω-3) and linoleic acid (18:2, ω-6) must be obtained from the diet — they serve as precursors for eicosanoids (prostaglandins, thromboxanes, leukotrienes) and structural membrane components
They are only needed during embryonic development and not in adulthood
questions.explanation: Humans possess Δ9, Δ6, and Δ5 desaturases that can introduce double bonds at positions up to Δ9 (9 carbons from the carboxyl end) in fatty acid chains. However, humans lack Δ12 and Δ15 (ω3) desaturases — enzymes found in plants and some microorganisms. Therefore, linoleic acid (18:2 Δ9,12, an ω-6 fatty acid) and α-linolenic acid (18:3 Δ9,12,15, an ω-3 fatty acid) cannot be synthesized and must come from the diet. Once obtained, these essential fatty acids are elongated and further desaturated to produce arachidonic acid (20:4 ω-6, precursor to series-2 prostaglandins and thromboxanes), EPA (20:5 ω-3), and DHA (22:6 ω-3, critical for brain and retina). The ω-6/ω-3 ratio in the diet influences inflammation: ω-6-derived eicosanoids are generally pro-inflammatory, while ω-3-derived are anti-inflammatory. Option A is wrong — humans cannot synthesize them. Option B is wrong. Option D is wrong — they are needed throughout life.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The quaternary structure of hemoglobin (α₂β₂ tetramer) enables cooperative oxygen binding. The molecular mechanism of cooperativity involves:
options: Each subunit folding independently with no communication between subunits
Covalent cross-links between α and β subunits that break upon oxygen binding

A conformational switch between the T (tense, low-affinity) and R (relaxed, high-affinity) states — oxygen binding to one subunit shifts the T↔R equilibrium toward R, increasing the oxygen affinity of remaining subunits, producing a sigmoidal binding curve
Random association and dissociation of subunits at each oxygen binding event
questions.explanation: Hemoglobin's cooperative oxygen binding is the textbook example of allosteric regulation. In the T-state (deoxy), salt bridges and hydrogen bonds between subunits constrain the molecule in a low-affinity conformation. When O₂ binds to one subunit, the iron atom moves into the porphyrin plane, pulling the proximal histidine (His F8) and the F helix, which disrupts the interface between subunits. This shifts the equilibrium from T to R state, where the other subunits have higher O₂ affinity (due to relaxed conformation of the heme pocket). The result is a sigmoidal (not hyperbolic) O₂ binding curve, enabling efficient O₂ loading in the lungs (high pO₂) and unloading in tissues (low pO₂). 2,3-BPG (bisphosphoglycerate), CO₂, and H⁺ are allosteric effectors that stabilize the T-state (Bohr effect). The Hill coefficient (~2.8) quantifies cooperativity. Option A ignores subunit communication. Option B is wrong — no covalent cross-links break. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Glycoproteins and proteoglycans both contain carbohydrate covalently attached to protein, but they differ fundamentally in that:
options: Glycoproteins contain 1-60% carbohydrate by weight (short, branched oligosaccharide chains), while proteoglycans contain up to 95% carbohydrate by weight (long, unbranched glycosaminoglycan chains like heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulfate, and hyaluronate)
Glycoproteins are found only inside cells while proteoglycans are found only outside cells
Proteoglycans do not contain protein — they are pure carbohydrate polymers
Both terms are interchangeable and describe the same molecules
questions.explanation: The key distinction is the proportion and type of carbohydrate. Glycoproteins have relatively short oligosaccharide chains (typically 1-15 sugar residues, sometimes longer) that constitute 1-60% of molecular weight. These include N-linked (to Asn) and O-linked (to Ser/Thr) glycans. Examples: antibodies, membrane receptors, mucins. Proteoglycans have one or more long, unbranched glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chains (chondroitin sulfate, heparan sulfate, keratan sulfate) that can contain hundreds of sugar residues and constitute 50-95% of molecular weight. GAGs are highly negatively charged (sulfate and carboxylate groups), attracting water and creating a gel-like extracellular matrix. Aggrecan (cartilage) has ~100 GAG chains and is 90% carbohydrate. Option B is wrong — both are found in multiple locations. Option C is wrong — proteoglycans do contain a protein core. Option D is wrong — they are distinct.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Chitin, the second most abundant organic polymer after cellulose, differs from cellulose in that:
options: Chitin uses α-glycosidic linkages while cellulose uses β-linkages

Chitin is made of N-acetylglucosamine (NAG) monomers joined by β-1,4 linkages — the acetamido group (-NHCOCH₃) at C-2 enables additional hydrogen bonding between chains, making chitin even harder and more resistant to degradation than cellulose
Chitin is a protein, not a polysaccharide
Cellulose is found in animals while chitin is found in plants
questions.explanation: Chitin is a polymer of N-acetylglucosamine (NAG, 2-acetamido-2-deoxy-D-glucose) linked by β-1,4 glycosidic bonds — the same linkage type as cellulose. The structural difference is the replacement of the C-2 hydroxyl group (in glucose/cellulose) with an N-acetyl group (-NHCOCH₃) in NAG/chitin. This acetamido group enables additional interchain hydrogen bonding (C=O···H-N), creating sheets that are stronger and more chemically resistant than cellulose. Chitin exists in three forms: α-chitin (antiparallel chains, most common, in arthropod exoskeletons), β-chitin (parallel chains, in squid pen), and γ-chitin (mixed). Chitin is found in arthropod exoskeletons, fungal cell walls, and mollusk radulae. Option A is wrong — both use β-1,4 linkages. Option C is wrong — chitin is a polysaccharide. Option D reverses the distribution.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The enzyme lysozyme catalyzes the hydrolysis of bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan by cleaving the β-1,4 glycosidic bond between N-acetylmuramic acid (NAM) and N-acetylglucosamine (NAG). The catalytic mechanism involves:
options: A simple acid-base mechanism using a single catalytic residue

A two-step mechanism: (1) Glu35 (protonated, acting as a general acid) donates a proton to the glycosidic oxygen, facilitating bond cleavage; (2) Asp52 (deprotonated, acting as a nucleophile or electrostatic stabilizer) stabilizes the resulting oxocarbenium ion intermediate at C-1 of NAM, which is then hydrolyzed by water
A radical mechanism involving free radical generation at the active site
Mechanical stress applied to the substrate through conformational changes, without any chemical catalysis
questions.explanation: Lysozyme (discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1922, first enzyme structure solved by X-ray crystallography in 1965 by Phillips) uses a double-displacement mechanism involving two key catalytic residues in its active site cleft. Glu35 (glutamic acid 35) is in a hydrophobic microenvironment that raises its pKa, keeping it protonated at physiological pH. It acts as a general acid catalyst, donating a proton to the glycosidic oxygen between NAM-NAG, weakening and breaking the bond. Asp52 (aspartate 52) is in a polar environment, keeping it deprotonated. It stabilizes the resulting positively charged oxocarbenium ion transition state at C-1 of NAM through electrostatic stabilization (or, in the revised mechanism, forms a covalent glycosyl-enzyme intermediate). Water then hydrolyzes the intermediate. The substrate is distorted into a half-chair conformation upon binding, which resembles the transition state. Option A is incomplete. Option C is wrong. Option D ignores chemical catalysis.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Prions are infectious misfolded proteins (PrPˢᶜ) that cause fatal neurodegenerative diseases. The 'protein-only' hypothesis states that:
options: Prions are actually viruses with nucleic acid genomes that have not yet been detected

PrPˢᶜ (scrapie form) converts normal cellular PrPᶜ to the misfolded PrPˢᶜ conformation through a template-directed mechanism — the misfolded form is rich in β-sheet (compared to the α-helix-rich PrPᶜ), is protease-resistant, and aggregates into amyloid fibrils
Prions are caused by bacterial toxins, not proteins
PrPᶜ and PrPˢᶜ have different amino acid sequences encoded by different genes
questions.explanation: Stanley Prusiner's protein-only hypothesis (1997 Nobel Prize) proposes that the infectious agent in prion diseases (scrapie, BSE/mad cow disease, CJD, kuru) is a misfolded protein — PrPˢᶜ — that propagates by converting the normal cellular form PrPᶜ to the PrPˢᶜ conformation. Both forms have identical amino acid sequences (encoded by the PRNP gene), but dramatically different secondary structures: PrPᶜ is ~42% α-helix and ~3% β-sheet, while PrPˢᶜ is ~30% α-helix and ~43% β-sheet. This conformational conversion occurs through physical contact (template-directed refolding). PrPˢᶜ is remarkably resistant to proteases, heat (survives autoclaving), UV radiation, and chemical denaturation. It aggregates into amyloid fibrils that accumulate in the brain, causing spongiform degeneration. Option A contradicts all evidence — no nucleic acid has been found. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong — same gene, same sequence.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Disaccharides are formed by glycosidic bonds between two monosaccharides. Sucrose (table sugar) is unique among common disaccharides because:
options: It is the only disaccharide that tastes sweet
It is a non-reducing sugar because the glycosidic bond links the anomeric carbons of both glucose (C-1) and fructose (C-2), leaving no free anomeric carbon available to act as a reducing agent
It contains two glucose molecules in an α-1,4 linkage
It is the only disaccharide that cannot be hydrolyzed by enzymes
questions.explanation: Sucrose is composed of glucose and fructose joined by an α-1,β-2 glycosidic bond. The 'α-1' indicates the bond originates from the anomeric carbon (C-1) of α-glucose, and 'β-2' indicates it connects to the anomeric carbon (C-2) of β-fructose. Because BOTH anomeric carbons are involved in the glycosidic bond, neither can open to expose a free aldehyde or ketone group. This makes sucrose a non-reducing sugar — it cannot reduce Cu²⁺ in Benedict's reagent or Ag⁺ in Tollens' reagent. In contrast, maltose (α-1,4 glucose-glucose) and lactose (β-1,4 galactose-glucose) each have one free anomeric carbon and ARE reducing sugars. Sucrose is hydrolyzed by the enzyme sucrase (invertase) in the small intestine. The 'inversion' of optical rotation upon hydrolysis (positive to negative) gave rise to the term 'invert sugar.' Option A is wrong. Option C describes maltose. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The amino acid composition of collagen is unusual because approximately 1/3 of its residues are glycine (Gly), and it contains significant amounts of hydroxyproline (Hyp) and hydroxylysine (Hyl). The biological reason for the high glycine content is:
options: Glycine is the only amino acid small enough (R group = H) to fit in the crowded interior of the collagen triple helix, where three polyproline II-type helices are wound tightly around each other — every third position must be glycine to accommodate the close packing
Glycine is the cheapest amino acid to synthesize, saving metabolic energy
Glycine provides the most hydrogen bonds per residue of any amino acid
Glycine is the only amino acid that can form disulfide bonds in collagen
questions.explanation: Collagen has a unique triple-helical structure: three left-handed polyproline II helices wind around each other in a right-handed superhelix. The interior of this triple helix is extremely crowded — only hydrogen (the R group of glycine) can fit in the interior position. Collagen's characteristic Gly-X-Y repeating sequence places glycine at every third position, where it is directed toward the helix interior. Position X is frequently proline (~28% of collagen), and position Y is frequently hydroxyproline (~38% of position Y). Hydroxyproline is formed by post-translational modification by prolyl-4-hydroxylase, which requires vitamin C (ascorbate) as a cofactor — this is why vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) causes collagen instability. The interchain hydrogen bonds (Gly N-H to C=O of residue in an adjacent chain) stabilize the triple helix. Mutations replacing Gly with larger amino acids cause osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease). Option B is irrelevant. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The β-pleated sheet secondary structure in proteins can exist in parallel and antiparallel orientations. The antiparallel β-sheet is generally more stable because:
options: Its hydrogen bonds are oriented nearly perpendicular to the strand direction and are linear (optimal geometry), while parallel β-sheet hydrogen bonds are angled and slightly longer, resulting in weaker interactions
It contains more amino acids per strand than parallel sheets
It can only form from hydrophobic amino acids
Antiparallel sheets are the only type found in nature
questions.explanation: In antiparallel β-sheets, adjacent strands run in opposite directions (N→C next to C→N). The hydrogen bonds between strands are nearly perpendicular to the strand direction and are linear (N-H···O=C at ~180°), which is the optimal geometry for hydrogen bond strength. In parallel β-sheets, adjacent strands run in the same direction, and the hydrogen bonds are angled (~160°) and slightly longer, making them slightly weaker. Antiparallel sheets are also easier to form locally because a single polypeptide chain can reverse direction through a β-turn (typically 4 residues involving Gly and Pro) to form an antiparallel hairpin. Parallel sheets usually require distant segments of the chain to align, often with a crossover connection. Both types are common in nature: antiparallel sheets are found in silk fibroin and immunoglobulin domains, while parallel sheets are found in α/β barrel enzymes. Option B is wrong. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong — both exist.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Lipid rafts in cell membranes are microdomains enriched in:
options: Unsaturated fatty acids and transmembrane proteins only

Sphingolipids, cholesterol, and GPI-anchored proteins — the saturated acyl chains of sphingolipids pack tightly with cholesterol, forming liquid-ordered (Lo) domains that are thicker and less fluid than the surrounding liquid-disordered (Ld) phospholipid bilayer
Only phosphatidylcholine and no other lipid species
Water-soluble vitamins and inorganic ions
questions.explanation: Lipid rafts are dynamic, nanometer-scale membrane microdomains (10-200 nm) enriched in sphingolipids (sphingomyelin, glycosphingolipids), cholesterol, and specific proteins (GPI-anchored proteins, doubly acylated proteins like Src family kinases). The long, predominantly saturated acyl chains of sphingolipids pack tightly together and with cholesterol's rigid steroid ring, forming liquid-ordered (Lo) phase domains that are thicker, more ordered, and less fluid than the surrounding phospholipid bilayer (liquid-disordered, Ld phase). Lipid rafts serve as platforms for signal transduction (concentrating receptors and signaling molecules), membrane trafficking, and pathogen entry (many viruses and bacteria exploit rafts for cell entry). Caveolae are a specialized type of raft stabilized by the protein caveolin. Option A is wrong — rafts are enriched in saturated lipids. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: RNA differs from DNA in three key structural features. Which statement correctly identifies all three?
options: RNA uses ribose sugar (2'-OH present), uracil instead of thymine, and is typically single-stranded (though it can form complex secondary and tertiary structures through intramolecular base pairing)
RNA uses deoxyribose sugar, uracil base, and is always double-stranded
RNA uses ribose sugar, cytosine instead of guanine, and is always linear
RNA and DNA are chemically identical and differ only in size
questions.explanation: Three structural differences distinguish RNA from DNA: (1) Sugar: RNA contains ribose (with a 2'-hydroxyl group), while DNA contains 2'-deoxyribose (lacking the 2'-OH). The 2'-OH in RNA makes it more susceptible to alkaline hydrolysis and gives RNA molecules a preference for A-form helical geometry. (2) Base: RNA contains uracil (U) in place of thymine (T). Uracil lacks the C-5 methyl group present on thymine; this methyl group in DNA helps the mismatch repair system distinguish U (from cytosine deamination damage) from T (a correct base). (3) Strandedness: DNA is typically double-stranded, while RNA is typically single-stranded but folds into complex secondary structures (hairpins, stem-loops, pseudoknots, bulges) and tertiary structures (ribozymes, riboswitches, rRNA). Option B reverses several features. Option C misidentifies the base change. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Enzyme kinetics distinguishes competitive from noncompetitive inhibition. In competitive inhibition:
options: The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex and cannot be overcome by increasing substrate
The inhibitor changes the enzyme's amino acid sequence
The inhibitor permanently modifies the enzyme through covalent modification
The inhibitor binds to the active site, competing with substrate — increasing substrate concentration can overcome the inhibition (Vmax unchanged, apparent Km increased)
questions.explanation: Competitive inhibitors bind reversibly to the enzyme's active site, competing directly with the substrate for the same binding site. At low [S], the inhibitor effectively reduces enzyme availability. However, at very high [S], substrate molecules outcompete the inhibitor, so Vmax is unchanged — the same maximum rate is achieved, just at higher substrate concentrations. The apparent Km increases (from Km to αKm, where α = 1 + [I]/Ki) because more substrate is needed to reach half-Vmax. Lineweaver-Burk plots show lines with the same y-intercept (1/Vmax) but different x-intercepts (-1/αKm). Classic examples include malonate (competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase, resembling the substrate succinate) and methotrexate (competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase). Option A describes noncompetitive or uncompetitive inhibition. Option C describes irreversible inhibition. Option B is impossible for an inhibitor.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The concept of 'induced fit' in enzyme catalysis, proposed by Daniel Koshland, states that:
options: The enzyme active site undergoes a conformational change upon substrate binding, optimizing the alignment of catalytic residues and stabilizing the transition state — this dynamic complementarity provides both specificity and catalytic power beyond what a rigid active site could achieve
Enzymes have rigid active sites that are pre-shaped exactly like the substrate (lock-and-key model)
Substrates change their structure to fit into a rigid enzyme
Enzymes do not have specific active sites and react with any molecule
questions.explanation: Koshland's induced fit model (1958) refined Fischer's lock-and-key model by recognizing that enzyme active sites are not rigid. Upon substrate binding, the enzyme undergoes conformational changes that: (1) optimize the positioning of catalytic residues (bringing them into precise alignment with the substrate bonds to be modified); (2) exclude water from the active site (creating a favorable microenvironment for catalysis); (3) strain or distort the substrate toward the transition state geometry; (4) create new binding interactions that stabilize the transition state. For example, hexokinase's two domains close around glucose like a clamp upon binding, excluding water and bringing the ATP γ-phosphate into proximity with glucose's C-6 hydroxyl. This explains why water (smaller than glucose) is not phosphorylated by hexokinase — it does not trigger the conformational change needed to close the active site. Option B describes the outdated lock-and-key model. Option C reverses the concept. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Waxes are lipids composed of a long-chain fatty acid esterified to a long-chain alcohol. Their biological function in many organisms is primarily:
options: Energy storage, serving as the primary fuel reserve in all animals
Acting as signaling molecules in hormonal cascades
Serving as a structural component of cell membranes in all organisms

Providing a hydrophobic, waterproof coating that prevents desiccation — found on plant leaf surfaces (cuticle), insect exoskeletons, bird feathers, and mammalian fur, where their high melting points (due to long, saturated chains) create solid, durable barriers
questions.explanation: Waxes consist of a long-chain fatty acid (typically C14-C36) ester-linked to a long-chain monohydric alcohol (typically C16-C30). The resulting molecule is extremely hydrophobic due to the very long hydrocarbon chains with no polar groups except the buried ester. Waxes have high melting points (typically 60-100°C) because the long, saturated chains pack very tightly through extensive van der Waals interactions. Their primary biological role is waterproofing: the plant cuticle (cuticular wax) prevents water loss from leaves; insect cuticle wax prevents desiccation of the exoskeleton; birds preen feathers with uropygial gland wax for waterproofing; lanolin (wool wax) protects sheep's wool; beeswax builds honeycomb structures; carnauba wax (from palm leaves) is one of the hardest natural waxes. Option A is wrong — fats, not waxes, are primary energy stores. Option C is wrong — phospholipids form membranes. Option B describes steroid hormones and eicosanoids.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about protein structure levels:
S1: Primary structure refers to the linear sequence of amino acids linked by peptide bonds, and it completely determines the three-dimensional structure of most proteins.
S2: Secondary structure (α-helices and β-sheets) is stabilized by hydrogen bonds between backbone N-H and C=O groups, not by side chain interactions.
S3: Tertiary structure involves the overall 3D folding of a single polypeptide chain, stabilized by hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and disulfide bridges between side chains.
S4: Quaternary structure, the association of multiple polypeptide subunits, is found in ALL proteins without exception.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Anfinsen's experiment demonstrated that the amino acid sequence (primary structure) contains all necessary information for a protein to fold into its correct 3D structure. While chaperones assist kinetically, the thermodynamic folding endpoint is sequence-determined. S2 is TRUE: α-helix hydrogen bonds (i→i+4) and β-sheet hydrogen bonds (between adjacent strands) involve only backbone N-H and C=O groups. Side chains project outward and do not participate in these secondary structure hydrogen bonds (though they influence which secondary structure is preferred). S3 is TRUE: Tertiary structure involves the complete 3D fold stabilized by multiple non-covalent interactions between side chains: hydrophobic core packing, hydrogen bonds, salt bridges (ionic bonds), and the covalent disulfide bonds between cysteine residues. S4 is FALSE: Quaternary structure requires multiple polypeptide chains. Many functional proteins are monomers (single chains) without quaternary structure — examples include myoglobin, lysozyme, ribonuclease A, and most enzymes.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about nucleic acid structure:
S1: The sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA runs in a 5'→3' direction, with the 5' end having a free phosphate group and the 3' end having a free hydroxyl group.
S2: DNA polymerase synthesizes new DNA in the 5'→3' direction by adding nucleotides to the 3'-OH of the growing chain.
S3: The two strands of double-stranded DNA run in the same direction (parallel) from 5' to 3'.
S4: A-form DNA has a wider, shallower major groove compared to B-form DNA, and A-form is adopted by RNA-DNA hybrids and double-stranded RNA.
options: T, T, F, T
T, T, T, F
F, T, F, T
T, F, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The DNA backbone consists of deoxyribose sugars linked by phosphodiester bonds. The 5' carbon of each sugar is connected to the phosphate group, and the 3' carbon connects to the next phosphate. By convention, the 5' end has a free or modified phosphate, and the 3' end has a free hydroxyl. S2 is TRUE: All known DNA polymerases synthesize DNA exclusively in the 5'→3' direction, adding deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs) to the 3'-OH of the growing strand via nucleophilic attack. This directionality necessitates the Okazaki fragment mechanism on the lagging strand. S3 is FALSE: The two strands of DNA are antiparallel — one runs 5'→3' while the complementary strand runs 3'→5'. This antiparallel arrangement is essential for Watson-Crick base pairing geometry. S4 is TRUE: A-form DNA/RNA has a wider and shallower major groove and a narrower, deeper minor groove compared to B-form DNA. The 2'-OH in RNA sterically prevents B-form geometry, forcing RNA duplexes into A-form.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about lipid structure and function:
S1: Triacylglycerols (fats) contain three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol backbone and serve primarily as energy storage molecules, yielding approximately 9 kcal/g upon complete oxidation.
S2: Phospholipids are amphipathic molecules that spontaneously form bilayers in aqueous solution, with the hydrophobic tails facing inward and hydrophilic heads facing outward.
S3: Steroids like cholesterol, estrogen, and testosterone are derived from a common 4-ring fused hydrocarbon structure and function as signaling molecules and membrane components.
S4: All lipids contain fatty acid chains as part of their structure.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, T, T
T, T, F, F
T, F, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Triacylglycerols (triglycerides) consist of glycerol with three fatty acid chains attached via ester bonds. They are the most concentrated form of energy storage (9 kcal/g vs 4 kcal/g for carbohydrates and proteins), because fatty acid carbons are more reduced (more C-H bonds) than carbohydrate carbons, yielding more electrons for the electron transport chain upon oxidation. S2 is TRUE: Phospholipids have a hydrophilic head (phosphate + alcohol) and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. In water, thermodynamic driving forces (hydrophobic effect) cause spontaneous bilayer self-assembly with tails sequestered in the interior. S3 is TRUE: All steroids share the 4-ring cyclopentanoperhydrophenanthrene (gonane) skeleton. Cholesterol is a membrane component and precursor to steroid hormones (cortisol, aldosterone, estradiol, testosterone), bile acids, and vitamin D. S4 is FALSE: Not all lipids contain fatty acids. Steroids (cholesterol, hormones) and terpenes (vitamins A, D, E, K) lack fatty acid chains.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about carbohydrate structure and function:
S1: Monosaccharides with 5 or more carbons exist predominantly in ring (cyclic) form in aqueous solution because intramolecular hemiacetal or hemiketal formation is thermodynamically favorable.
S2: The glycocalyx (cell surface carbohydrate coating) functions in cell-cell recognition, immune response, and protection of the cell surface.
S3: Lactose intolerance results from deficiency of the enzyme lactase, which hydrolyzes the β-1,4 glycosidic bond between galactose and glucose in lactose.
S4: All polysaccharides are digestible by human enzymes.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: In aqueous solution, monosaccharides with ≥5 carbons undergo intramolecular nucleophilic addition, where a hydroxyl group attacks the carbonyl carbon, forming a cyclic hemiacetal (from aldoses) or hemiketal (from ketoses). For glucose at 25°C, >99% exists in the ring form (pyranose), with <0.003% in the open-chain form. This equilibrium favors ring closure because it reduces the strain of the open-chain form. S2 is TRUE: The glycocalyx consists of carbohydrate portions of glycoproteins, glycolipids, and proteoglycans on the cell surface. It mediates cell-cell recognition (blood type antigens, selectin binding), immune response (MHC glycosylation, pathogen recognition), and physical protection. S3 is TRUE: Lactase (β-galactosidase) cleaves the β-1,4 bond in lactose. Most adult humans (except those with lactase persistence, common in populations with long dairy-farming history) downregulate lactase after weaning. S4 is FALSE: Humans cannot digest cellulose (β-1,4 glucose) or chitin (β-1,4 NAG) because we lack β-glycosidases.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
A researcher studies protein denaturation by measuring the fraction of unfolded protein at various temperatures for three different proteins:

| Temperature (°C) | Protein A (% unfolded) | Protein B (% unfolded) | Protein C (% unfolded) |
|-------------------|------------------------|------------------------|------------------------|
| 30                | 2                      | 5                      | 50                     |
| 40                | 5                      | 50                     | 85                     |
| 50                | 50                     | 95                     | 98                     |
| 60                | 90                     | 99                     | 99                     |
| 70                | 99                     | 99.5                   | 99.5                   |

Which protein is most thermostable, and what structural features might explain its stability?
options: Protein C, because it unfolds at the lowest temperature, indicating thermal stability
Protein B, because it has moderate unfolding behavior at all temperatures

Protein A, with Tm ≈ 50°C — it is most thermostable because 50% unfolding occurs at the highest temperature, likely due to features such as increased hydrophobic core packing, more salt bridges, higher proline content, or more disulfide bonds
All three proteins are equally thermostable because they all reach 99% unfolding by 70°C
questions.explanation: Thermal stability is measured by the melting temperature (Tm), defined as the temperature at which 50% of the protein is unfolded. From the data: Protein A Tm ≈ 50°C, Protein B Tm ≈ 40°C, Protein C Tm ≈ 30°C. Protein A is therefore the most thermostable. Structural features that enhance thermostability (well-documented from thermophilic organisms) include: (1) increased hydrophobic core packing (more buried hydrophobic surface area); (2) additional salt bridges and ion pairs (Arg-Asp/Glu); (3) higher proline content in loops (restricting backbone flexibility); (4) more disulfide bonds; (5) shorter and fewer loops; (6) increased hydrogen bonding networks; (7) oligomerization (quaternary structure). Thermophilic proteins from organisms like Thermus aquaticus (source of Taq polymerase) have Tm values exceeding 80°C. Option A confuses lower Tm with higher stability. Option B is not the most stable. Option D ignores the different Tm values.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
The following table shows the amino acid composition of two proteins:

| Property          | Protein X       | Protein Y        |
|-------------------|-----------------|------------------|
| % Hydrophobic AA  | 55%             | 30%              |
| % Charged AA      | 12%             | 35%              |
| % Gly             | 5%              | 33%              |
| % Pro + Hyp       | 3%              | 22%              |
| Molecular weight  | 45 kDa          | 285 kDa (trimer) |
| Location          | Cytoplasm       | Extracellular    |

Based on amino acid composition and location, which proteins do these most likely represent?
options: Protein X is hemoglobin and Protein Y is myoglobin
Both are membrane proteins embedded in the lipid bilayer
Protein X is a typical globular enzyme (high hydrophobic content for core packing, cytoplasmic), while Protein Y is collagen (high Gly + Pro/Hyp, trimeric, extracellular)
Protein X is a structural fiber and Protein Y is a soluble enzyme
questions.explanation: The amino acid compositions are diagnostic. Protein X: 55% hydrophobic amino acids (typical for globular proteins, where ~50-60% of residues are buried in the hydrophobic core), 12% charged (surface residues), low Gly and Pro, 45 kDa monomer, cytoplasmic — this profile matches a typical globular enzyme like a kinase or dehydrogenase. Protein Y: 33% glycine (every third residue), 22% proline + hydroxyproline, 285 kDa trimer, extracellular — this is the signature profile of collagen. The Gly-X-Y repeat (where X is often Pro and Y is often Hyp) is unique to collagen. The trimeric structure corresponds to the characteristic triple helix. The extracellular location is consistent with collagen's role in the extracellular matrix. Option A is wrong — neither profile matches hemoglobin or myoglobin. Option B is wrong — neither has the hydrophobic transmembrane segments typical of membrane proteins. Option D reverses the assignments.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
A biochemistry lab measures the iodine number (amount of I₂ absorbed per 100g of fat, measuring degree of unsaturation) for different dietary fats:

| Fat source    | Iodine number | Physical state at 25°C |
|---------------|---------------|------------------------|
| Coconut oil   | 8-10          | Solid                  |
| Butter        | 26-42         | Soft solid             |
| Olive oil     | 80-88         | Liquid                 |
| Sunflower oil | 125-140       | Liquid                 |
| Linseed oil   | 170-204       | Liquid                 |

What relationship does this data demonstrate?
options: Higher iodine numbers indicate more saturated fats with higher melting points
Iodine number has no correlation with the physical state of fats

Higher iodine numbers indicate greater unsaturation (more C=C double bonds that react with I₂), which correlates with lower melting points and liquid state at room temperature — because cis double bonds create kinks that prevent tight packing of fatty acid chains
All fats with iodine numbers above 50 are synthetically produced
questions.explanation: The iodine number quantifies the degree of unsaturation: I₂ adds across C=C double bonds (halogenation), so more double bonds = more I₂ absorbed = higher iodine number. The data clearly shows an inverse relationship between iodine number and melting point/physical state. Coconut oil (iodine number 8-10) is highly saturated with predominantly lauric acid (12:0) and myristic acid (14:0), which pack tightly — solid at 25°C. Olive oil (80-88) is rich in oleic acid (18:1 cis-Δ9), a monounsaturated fat — liquid at 25°C. Linseed oil (170-204) is rich in α-linolenic acid (18:3 ω-3), a highly polyunsaturated fat — very fluid liquid. Each cis double bond introduces a ~30° kink that disrupts chain packing, lowering the melting point. This principle underlies membrane fluidity regulation and the health effects of dietary fat composition. Option A reverses the relationship. Option B is wrong. Option D is wrong — all listed fats are natural.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: To determine whether a newly discovered protein functions as a tetramer (quaternary structure) rather than a monomer in its native state, a researcher should use:
options: SDS-PAGE alone, which determines native oligomeric state
Amino acid sequencing by Edman degradation

A combination of size-exclusion chromatography (SEC, measures native molecular weight), analytical ultracentrifugation (measures sedimentation coefficient), and native PAGE (separates by size and charge without denaturation) — comparing native MW to the subunit MW determined by SDS-PAGE
Western blotting with an antibody to detect the protein
questions.explanation: Determining quaternary structure requires comparing the molecular weight of the native protein complex to the molecular weight of individual subunits. SDS-PAGE (option A) determines SUBUNIT molecular weight because SDS denatures the protein and dissociates oligomeric complexes — it cannot reveal the native state. The correct approach combines: (1) SDS-PAGE to determine monomer MW (e.g., 30 kDa); (2) Size-exclusion chromatography (SEC/gel filtration) under native conditions to estimate native MW (e.g., 120 kDa), suggesting a tetramer (120/30 = 4 subunits); (3) Analytical ultracentrifugation to independently confirm native MW from sedimentation behavior; (4) Native PAGE or blue native PAGE to separate the intact complex. Cross-linking followed by SDS-PAGE can also reveal oligomeric contacts. If native MW ≈ 4× subunit MW, the protein is a tetramer. Option B determines sequence, not quaternary structure. Option D detects presence but not oligomeric state.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: A student wants to test whether a specific amino acid residue (Asp102) is essential for the catalytic activity of a serine protease. The most rigorous approach would be:
options: Simply observing the protein crystal structure and concluding that any residue near the active site must be catalytic
Removing the entire protein from the cell and measuring the effect on cellular function

Site-directed mutagenesis to replace Asp102 with Asn (D102N), purifying the mutant enzyme, comparing its kinetic parameters (kcat, Km, kcat/Km) to wild-type, and measuring pH-activity profiles to show the loss of the expected pKa shift associated with the catalytic aspartate
Running the enzyme on a gel and comparing its migration distance to known molecular weight standards
questions.explanation: Site-directed mutagenesis is the gold standard for identifying catalytic residues. The D102N mutation (Asp→Asn) is a conservative substitution: asparagine has the same size and shape as aspartate but lacks the carboxylate negative charge — it replaces -COO⁻ with -CONH₂. If Asp102 is part of the catalytic triad (Ser-His-Asp), its negative charge is essential for orienting and polarizing His57, which in turn activates Ser195 as a nucleophile. The D102N mutant should show: (1) dramatically reduced kcat (typically 10³-10⁴ fold decrease); (2) relatively unchanged Km (substrate still binds); (3) shifted pH-activity profile (loss of the pKa contribution from Asp102). Comparing kinetic parameters (Michaelis-Menten analysis) and pH profiles provides quantitative evidence. This approach was used to definitively establish the catalytic roles of the serine protease triad residues. Option A provides correlation but not causation. Option B is too indirect. Option D measures size, not activity.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Amyloid fibrils are associated with neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer's (Aβ peptide) and Parkinson's (α-synuclein). The structural hallmark of amyloid is:
options: A native α-helical conformation that is abnormally stable
A collagen-like triple helix that aggregates in the brain
A random coil with no regular secondary structure
A cross-β structure in which β-strands run perpendicular to the fibril axis, with backbone hydrogen bonds running parallel to the axis, creating extremely stable, protease-resistant fibers
questions.explanation: Amyloid fibrils share a characteristic 'cross-β' structural motif regardless of the protein's native structure. In this arrangement, β-strands from multiple protein molecules stack perpendicular to the fibril long axis, with the backbone hydrogen bonds running parallel to the axis (along the fibril). This creates a rigid, thermodynamically stable structure resistant to proteolysis, detergents, and heat. X-ray fiber diffraction shows characteristic reflections at 4.7 Å (inter-strand distance along the axis) and 10-12 Å (inter-sheet distance). Amyloid formation involves: (1) partial unfolding or misfolding; (2) nucleation (rate-limiting); (3) fibril elongation through templated addition of monomers; (4) secondary nucleation and fragmentation. Thioflavin T (ThT) fluorescence and Congo red birefringence are diagnostic stains. Amyloid is found in many diseases: Alzheimer's (Aβ42), Parkinson's (α-synuclein), Huntington's (huntingtin), type 2 diabetes (IAPP/amylin), and prion diseases (PrP). Option A is wrong. Option C is wrong. Option B is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The fluid mosaic model of membrane structure, proposed by Singer and Nicolson (1972), describes the cell membrane as:
options: A rigid lattice of phospholipids with fixed protein positions
A triple-layered structure of protein-lipid-protein observed by electron microscopy
A single layer of phospholipids with proteins on only one surface

A two-dimensional fluid phospholipid bilayer in which integral and peripheral membrane proteins are embedded and can move laterally, with the distribution of lipids and proteins being heterogeneous (mosaic-like) and dynamic
questions.explanation: The fluid mosaic model describes the membrane as a dynamic structure with two key properties: (1) Fluidity — the phospholipid bilayer behaves as a two-dimensional fluid in which individual lipids undergo rapid lateral diffusion (~2 μm/s) and rotational motion, while transverse diffusion (flip-flop) is extremely slow (t½ ~hours to days) without flippases. Integral membrane proteins also diffuse laterally but more slowly than lipids due to their larger size. (2) Mosaic — the distribution of lipids and proteins is heterogeneous, forming a mosaic pattern of different molecular species. Modern updates to the model include recognition of lipid rafts, cytoskeletal fences (restricting protein diffusion), asymmetric lipid distribution between leaflets, and crowded protein surfaces (30% of membrane area is protein). Option A contradicts the fluidity concept. Option C describes a monolayer. Option B describes the outdated Davson-Danielli model.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Allosteric enzymes display sigmoidal kinetics rather than Michaelis-Menten hyperbolic kinetics. This sigmoidal response is biologically advantageous because:
options: It allows the enzyme to operate at a constant rate regardless of substrate concentration
It eliminates the need for any regulation of enzyme activity
Sigmoidal kinetics means the enzyme is always inhibited

It creates a switch-like response where enzyme activity increases sharply over a narrow substrate concentration range, enabling sensitive metabolic regulation — a small change in [S] near K₀.₅ produces a large change in reaction rate
questions.explanation: Allosteric enzymes with sigmoidal (cooperative) kinetics display an ultrasensitive response to substrate concentration. Unlike Michaelis-Menten enzymes (which require an 81-fold change in [S] to go from 10% to 90% Vmax), allosteric enzymes with a Hill coefficient of 4 require only a ~3-fold change in [S] for the same transition. This switch-like behavior is ideal for metabolic regulation: metabolic pathways can be rapidly turned 'on' or 'off' by relatively small changes in metabolite concentration. For example, phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), the key regulatory enzyme of glycolysis, shows sigmoidal kinetics with respect to fructose-6-phosphate and is allosterically activated by AMP/ADP and inhibited by ATP/citrate. This allows glycolysis to respond sensitively to cellular energy status. The K₀.₅ (equivalent of Km for allosteric enzymes) replaces Km. Option A contradicts sigmoidal behavior. Option C is wrong. Option B is the opposite of the truth.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Glycosylation is the most common post-translational modification of proteins. N-linked glycosylation begins in the endoplasmic reticulum with the transfer of a 14-sugar oligosaccharide (Glc₃Man₉GlcNAc₂) from dolichol phosphate to:
options: Any amino acid residue on the protein surface
The N-terminal amino group of the polypeptide chain
The serine or threonine hydroxyl group in the cytoplasm

The asparagine (Asn) side chain amide nitrogen within a specific consensus sequence (Asn-X-Ser/Thr, where X is any amino acid except proline), catalyzed by oligosaccharyltransferase (OST) as the polypeptide enters the ER lumen during translation
questions.explanation: N-linked glycosylation is a co-translational modification that occurs as the polypeptide is translocated into the ER lumen. The enzyme oligosaccharyltransferase (OST), located on the luminal face of the ER membrane, transfers a pre-assembled 14-sugar 'core' oligosaccharide (Glc₃Man₉GlcNAc₂) from the lipid carrier dolichol pyrophosphate to the amide nitrogen of asparagine within the consensus sequon Asn-X-Ser/Thr (where X ≠ Pro). Not all potential sites are glycosylated — accessibility, protein folding, and local structure affect whether a sequon is modified. After transfer, the oligosaccharide is processed by glucosidases and mannosidases in the ER (quality control, calnexin/calreticulin cycle) and Golgi (trimming and addition of sugars for complex, hybrid, or high-mannose types). Option A is wrong — glycosylation is site-specific. Option C describes O-linked glycosylation. Option B is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The phosphodiester bond in nucleic acids links:
options: The nitrogenous base to the sugar at the anomeric carbon (N-glycosidic bond)
Two nucleotides through a phosphate group that bridges the 3'-hydroxyl of one sugar to the 5'-hydroxyl of the next sugar, creating the backbone of DNA and RNA with alternating sugar-phosphate units
Two phosphate groups together (phosphoanhydride bond) as in ATP
The 2'-hydroxyl of ribose to the phosphate of the adjacent nucleotide
questions.explanation: The phosphodiester bond is the covalent linkage that joins nucleotides in DNA and RNA. It involves a phosphate group forming two ester bonds: one to the 3'-OH of one sugar and another to the 5'-OH of the adjacent sugar. This 3'→5' phosphodiester linkage creates the sugar-phosphate backbone of nucleic acids. The bond is formed by nucleic acid polymerases (DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase) through nucleophilic attack of the 3'-OH on the α-phosphate of an incoming nucleoside triphosphate, with release of pyrophosphate (PPi). The subsequent hydrolysis of PPi by pyrophosphatase makes polymerization thermodynamically irreversible. Phosphodiester bonds are extremely stable kinetically (half-life ~30 million years for DNA at pH 7, 25°C) but can be cleaved by nucleases (endonucleases cut within the chain, exonucleases trim from ends). Option A describes the N-glycosidic bond. Option C describes phosphoanhydride bonds. Option D describes an incorrect connectivity.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The hydrophobic effect is the dominant force driving protein folding. Quantitatively, burying hydrophobic surface area during folding contributes approximately:
options: Less than 1% of the total folding free energy
Exactly 0 kcal/mol because the hydrophobic effect does not contribute to protein stability

Approximately -25 cal/mol per Å² of buried nonpolar surface area, which for a typical protein amounts to -100 to -300 kcal/mol of hydrophobic stabilization, partially offset by the conformational entropy penalty of folding
Over 10,000 kcal/mol, making proteins the most stable biological structures
questions.explanation: The hydrophobic effect provides approximately -25 cal/mol per Å² of buried nonpolar surface area. A typical 150-residue protein buries approximately 4000-12,000 Å² of nonpolar surface during folding, yielding -100 to -300 kcal/mol of favorable free energy. However, this large favorable contribution is almost entirely offset by the unfavorable conformational entropy penalty (-TΔS ≈ +100-200 kcal/mol) — folding restricts the chain from millions of conformations to essentially one. The net stability of a folded protein is remarkably small: ΔG_folding ≈ -5 to -15 kcal/mol (20-60 kJ/mol), equivalent to just a few hydrogen bonds. This marginal stability is biologically important: it allows proteins to undergo conformational changes during function and enables regulated degradation. The hydrophobic effect, hydrogen bonding, van der Waals interactions, and electrostatic interactions all contribute, with hydrophobic effect being the largest single contributor. Option A vastly underestimates. Option B is wrong. Option D vastly overestimates.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Sphingolipids differ from glycerophospholipids in their backbone structure. The sphingolipid backbone is:
options: Glycerol, identical to glycerophospholipids

Sphingosine (an 18-carbon amino alcohol with a trans double bond), to which a fatty acid is attached via an amide bond at C-2, creating ceramide — the precursor to sphingomyelin, cerebrosides, and gangliosides
Cholesterol, to which sugars are attached
A simple hydrocarbon chain with no functional groups
questions.explanation: Sphingolipids are built on a sphingosine backbone — a long-chain amino alcohol (2-amino-4-trans-octadecene-1,3-diol). Sphingosine has: an amino group at C-2, two hydroxyl groups (C-1 and C-3), and a trans C4-C5 double bond followed by a 13-carbon saturated chain. When a fatty acid is attached to the C-2 amino group via an amide bond (not an ester), the resulting molecule is ceramide.
