Ceramide is the precursor for all sphingolipids: adding phosphocholine gives sphingomyelin (the only sphingophospholipid); adding single sugars gives cerebrosides (galactocerebroside in myelin); adding oligosaccharides with sialic acid gives gangliosides (GM1, GM2, GM3 — important in brain). Sphingolipids are enriched in lipid rafts and are important in cell signaling (ceramide is a pro-apoptotic signal). Sphingolipid storage diseases (Tay-Sachs, Gaucher's, Niemann-Pick) result from deficiencies in degradation enzymes. Option A is wrong — sphingolipids use sphingosine, not glycerol. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The Ramachandran plot for glycine residues is notably different from that of other amino acids because:
options: Glycine has no side chain beyond a hydrogen atom (R = H), which eliminates steric clashes with the backbone, allowing glycine access to a much larger region of φ/ψ space — including the left-handed α-helix region that is forbidden for most other residues
Glycine has the largest side chain, causing the most steric clashes
Glycine cannot form peptide bonds and therefore has no defined backbone angles
Glycine adopts only the β-sheet conformation and no other
questions.explanation: Glycine is unique because its side chain is simply a hydrogen atom (the smallest possible R group). In other amino acids, the Cβ atom (and further side chain atoms) creates steric clashes with backbone atoms at certain φ/ψ combinations, restricting approximately 80% of conformational space. Glycine, lacking a Cβ, experiences no such restrictions. Its Ramachandran plot shows allowed regions covering much more of the φ/ψ map — approximately 50-60% of theoretical space is accessible, compared to ~20% for alanine or larger residues. Glycine can adopt the left-handed α-helix conformation (φ ≈ +57°, ψ ≈ +47°), which is sterically forbidden for L-amino acids with Cβ. This conformational flexibility makes glycine essential at positions requiring tight turns (β-turns, loops) or where the backbone must adopt unusual conformations (collagen: Gly must be at every third position). Option B is the opposite. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Lectins are proteins that specifically bind carbohydrates. Their biological significance includes:
options: They are found only in plants and have no animal homologs
They serve as structural proteins in cell walls but have no recognition function

They mediate cell-cell adhesion (selectins in immune cell trafficking), pathogen recognition (mannose-binding lectin in innate immunity), and quality control of glycoprotein folding in the ER (calnexin/calreticulin cycle)
They catalyze the hydrolysis of carbohydrates like amylase does
questions.explanation: Lectins are carbohydrate-binding proteins (not enzymes — they bind but do not modify sugars) found in all domains of life. Important biological roles include: (1) Cell adhesion: Selectins (E-, P-, L-selectin) on endothelial cells and leukocytes bind specific carbohydrate ligands (sialyl-Lewis X), mediating the rolling adhesion step of leukocyte extravasation during inflammation. (2) Innate immunity: Mannose-binding lectin (MBL) in serum recognizes mannose/GlcNAc on pathogen surfaces and activates the lectin complement pathway. DC-SIGN on dendritic cells binds high-mannose glycans. (3) ER quality control: Calnexin and calreticulin are lectins that bind monoglucosylated N-glycans on newly synthesized glycoproteins, retaining misfolded proteins for another folding attempt. (4) Plant defense: Concanavalin A and other plant lectins bind to herbivore gut glycoproteins, acting as antifeedants. Option A is wrong. Option B is wrong. Option D describes glycosidases, not lectins.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The energy yield from complete oxidation of a triglyceride versus glucose on a per-gram basis differs because:
options: Fat carbons are more reduced (average oxidation state ≈ -2) than glucose carbons (average oxidation state ≈ 0), so fat yields more electrons per carbon upon oxidation, and fat is anhydrous while glycogen binds ~2g water per gram, making the effective energy density advantage of fat even greater (~9 kcal/g vs ~1 kcal/g hydrated glycogen)
Glucose has more C-H bonds per gram than fatty acids
Glucose is oxidized more efficiently than fat because glycolysis is more energy-efficient than β-oxidation
Fat and glucose yield identical energy per gram; the difference is only in speed of metabolism
questions.explanation: Fat yields ~9 kcal/g versus ~4 kcal/g for carbohydrate upon complete oxidation, for two fundamental chemical reasons. First, fat carbons are more reduced: in palmitate (C₁₆H₃₂O₂), the average carbon oxidation state is approximately -2, while in glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆), it is 0. More reduced carbons have more electrons to donate to the electron transport chain upon oxidation to CO₂. Second, fats are nearly anhydrous in adipose tissue, while glycogen is hydrated (binding ~2g water per gram of glycogen). This means the effective energy density of glycogen in vivo is only ~1 kcal/g (4 kcal/g ÷ 3 g total weight per g glycogen). The combined effect makes fat ~9× more energy-dense than hydrated glycogen per unit mass, explaining why fat is the preferred long-term energy storage form. A 70 kg human stores ~135,000 kcal as fat but only ~600 kcal as glycogen. Option B reverses the comparison. Option C is incorrect. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Protein domains are independently folding units within a polypeptide. The immunoglobulin (Ig) fold domain is found in many proteins beyond antibodies because:
options: It is the only protein fold that exists in nature

The Ig fold (a β-sandwich of two antiparallel β-sheets connected by a conserved disulfide bond) is an evolutionarily versatile module that has been duplicated and diversified for diverse functions including immune recognition (antibodies, TCRs, MHC), cell adhesion (cadherins, integrins), and signaling (receptor tyrosine kinases)
It was artificially introduced into these proteins by genetic engineering
All proteins with β-sheets automatically have the Ig fold
questions.explanation: The immunoglobulin fold is one of the most common protein domain architectures, found in over 2,500 proteins in the human proteome (the 'Ig superfamily'). The domain consists of approximately 70-110 amino acids arranged as two antiparallel β-sheets packed face-to-face (a β-sandwich), typically stabilized by a conserved disulfide bond. This fold is remarkably versatile because: (1) the loop regions connecting β-strands can tolerate extensive sequence variation (creating antibody CDRs for antigen recognition); (2) domains can be concatenated in tandem (antibody light chain = 2 Ig domains, heavy chain = 4-5 domains, titin = 244 Ig domains); (3) the stable core tolerates diverse surface modifications. Members include: antibodies, T cell receptors, MHC molecules, CD4/CD8 co-receptors, VCAM/ICAM adhesion molecules, PDGF receptor, and many more. Option A is wrong. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong — many β-sheet proteins lack the Ig fold.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The anomeric effect in carbohydrate chemistry refers to the preference of substituents at C-1 (the anomeric carbon) of pyranose sugars to adopt the axial orientation. In glucose, this means:
options: α-D-glucopyranose (axial -OH at C-1) is thermodynamically more stable than predicted by steric considerations alone, due to favorable interactions between the lone pair orbitals on the ring oxygen and the C-1 substituent
β-D-glucopyranose is always 100% of the equilibrium mixture
The anomeric carbon has no special chemical properties different from other carbons in the ring
Both α and β anomers are always present in exactly equal amounts at equilibrium
questions.explanation: The anomeric effect is the tendency of electronegative substituents at the anomeric carbon (C-1) of pyranose sugars to prefer the axial orientation, contrary to what would be predicted from steric considerations alone (which favor equatorial). In aqueous solution, D-glucose exists as an equilibrium mixture of ~36% α (axial -OH at C-1) and ~64% β (equatorial -OH at C-1). While β predominates (equatorial position avoids 1,3-diaxial interactions), the α form is present in higher proportion than predicted by sterics alone — this is the anomeric effect. The effect arises from hyperconjugation: the lone pair on the ring oxygen (O-5) donates electron density into the σ* antibonding orbital of the C-1-O-1 bond when the substituent is axial, stabilizing this conformation. For sugars with more electronegative substituents (e.g., fluorine at C-1), the anomeric effect is stronger. Option B is wrong. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong — the ratio is not 50:50.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) challenge the traditional structure-function paradigm. They are significant because:
options: They represent errors in protein synthesis that are always degraded immediately

They lack stable secondary and tertiary structure under physiological conditions but perform essential functions including signaling, transcriptional regulation, and binding to multiple partners — their flexibility allows them to adopt different conformations upon binding different targets (coupled folding and binding)
They are found only in prokaryotes and have been eliminated from eukaryotic genomes
They always fold into a stable structure before they can function
questions.explanation: Approximately 30-50% of eukaryotic proteins contain significant regions of intrinsic disorder (no stable 3D structure in isolation). These IDPs or intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) are not misfolded or denatured — they are functional in their disordered state. Key biological roles include: (1) Signaling hubs: p53's transactivation domain is disordered and binds >100 different partners through 'coupled folding and binding' — adopting different conformations with each partner. (2) Transcription factors: Many transcription factor activation domains are disordered. (3) Phase separation: IDPs with low-complexity sequences drive formation of membraneless organelles (stress granules, P bodies, nucleolus) through liquid-liquid phase separation. (4) Post-translational modification: Disordered regions are enriched in phosphorylation, ubiquitination, and acetylation sites. IDPs evolve faster than structured proteins because fewer structural constraints limit sequence variation. Option A is wrong. Option C is wrong. Option D contradicts the evidence.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The structure of A-DNA, B-DNA, and Z-DNA differ in helix geometry. Z-DNA is unusual because:
options: It is a left-handed double helix with a zigzag sugar-phosphate backbone, typically formed in alternating purine-pyrimidine sequences (especially dCG repeats) under conditions of high salt or cytosine methylation, and may play roles in transcriptional regulation and chromosome structure
It is a right-handed helix like B-DNA but with a narrower major groove
It is single-stranded and cannot form a duplex
It is only found in synthetic DNA and never occurs in living organisms
questions.explanation: Z-DNA is a left-handed double helix (the only left-handed form of DNA) first crystallized by Alexander Rich in 1979. Its sugar-phosphate backbone follows a zigzag pattern (hence 'Z') because alternating purines and pyrimidines adopt different sugar puckers (C2'-endo for pyrimidines, C3'-endo for purines). Z-DNA has 12 base pairs per turn (vs 10 for B-DNA), a narrower and more elongated helix (18 Å diameter vs 20 Å for B-DNA), and essentially no major groove (it is very shallow). Z-DNA formation is favored by alternating dCG sequences, high salt (> 2.5 M NaCl), cytosine methylation (5-methylcytosine), and negative supercoiling. Biological relevance: Z-DNA-specific binding proteins (Zα domain) exist; Z-DNA may form at actively transcribed gene promoters due to negative supercoiling generated behind the advancing RNA polymerase. ADAR1 contains a Zα domain that recognizes Z-DNA/Z-RNA. Option B is wrong — Z-DNA is left-handed. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Proteomics studies reveal that the human proteome is far more complex than the ~20,000 protein-coding genes would suggest. This complexity arises from:
options: Each gene always encodes exactly one protein with one function

Alternative splicing (generating multiple mRNA variants from one gene), post-translational modifications (phosphorylation, glycosylation, ubiquitination, acetylation, methylation), proteolytic processing, and protein-protein interactions that create a proteome estimated at >1 million distinct protein forms (proteoforms)
Random mutations that constantly change the proteome
External proteins from food that are incorporated directly into the human proteome
questions.explanation: The human proteome vastly exceeds gene count through multiple mechanisms: (1) Alternative splicing: ~95% of multi-exon human genes undergo alternative splicing, generating 2-100+ mRNA variants per gene. The DSCAM gene in Drosophila can produce 38,016 splice variants. (2) Post-translational modifications (PTMs): >400 types of PTMs have been cataloged, including phosphorylation (~13,000 sites in the human proteome), glycosylation, ubiquitination, acetylation, methylation, lipidation, and SUMOylation. Each PTM creates a functionally distinct proteoform. (3) Proteolytic processing: Prohormones (proinsulin, pro-opiomelanocortin), zymogens (trypsinogen), and signal peptide cleavage. (4) Combinatorial protein-protein interactions: Different subunit combinations in oligomeric proteins. The concept of 'proteoforms' (distinct molecular forms of a protein) captures this complexity — the human proteome may contain >1 million proteoforms. Option A is the 'one gene, one enzyme' oversimplification. Option C is too random. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Ribozymes challenge the traditional view that only proteins can catalyze biological reactions. The discovery of catalytic RNA was significant because:
options: It proved that proteins are not important in biology

It supported the 'RNA world' hypothesis — that early life may have used RNA both as genetic material and as catalysts, before proteins took over catalytic functions and DNA took over information storage
Ribozymes catalyze reactions faster than any protein enzyme
Ribozymes are found only in bacteria and have no eukaryotic examples
questions.explanation: Thomas Cech (self-splicing Tetrahymena rRNA intron, 1982) and Sidney Altman (RNase P, 1983) shared the 1989 Nobel Prize for discovering that RNA can catalyze chemical reactions. This discovery had profound implications for understanding the origin of life: the 'RNA world' hypothesis proposes that early life used RNA as both informational molecule (genetic storage) and functional molecule (catalysis), solving the chicken-and-egg problem of which came first — DNA or proteins. RNA can perform both functions. Known ribozymes include: Group I/II introns (self-splicing), RNase P (tRNA processing), hammerhead ribozyme (plant viral RNA cleavage), ribosome (peptidyl transferase — the ribosome is a ribozyme!), spliceosome (mRNA splicing). While ribozymes are generally slower catalysts than protein enzymes (with some exceptions), the ribosome catalyzes peptide bond formation at ~15-20 bonds per second. Option A is an overstatement. Option C is generally wrong. Option D is wrong — ribozymes exist in all domains.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Blood group antigens (ABO system) are determined by specific carbohydrate modifications on the surface of red blood cells. The A, B, and O phenotypes differ in:
options: The terminal sugar added to the H antigen precursor: type A has N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) added by glycosyltransferase A, type B has galactose (Gal) added by glycosyltransferase B, and type O has an inactive enzyme that adds no terminal sugar, leaving the unmodified H antigen
The protein carrier molecule on the RBC surface
The lipid composition of the RBC membrane
The DNA sequence of the hemoglobin gene
questions.explanation: The ABO blood group system is determined by glycosyltransferase enzymes that modify the H antigen on RBC surfaces. The H antigen is a carbohydrate chain (with terminal fucose) on glycoproteins and glycolipids. Glycosyltransferase A (encoded by the A allele) adds N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen, creating the A antigen. Glycosyltransferase B (B allele) adds galactose (Gal), creating the B antigen. The O allele encodes a truncated, nonfunctional enzyme (due to a frameshift mutation), so no sugar is added and the H antigen remains unmodified. AB individuals have both functional enzymes and express both A and B antigens. The antibodies against foreign blood group antigens (anti-A, anti-B) are produced in response to gut bacteria bearing similar carbohydrate epitopes. This explains transfusion compatibility rules. Option B is wrong — the protein is the same. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong — it's about carbohydrate chemistry, not hemoglobin.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Protein misfolding and aggregation are implicated in many diseases collectively known as 'proteinopathies.' The common feature of proteins involved in these diseases is:
options: They are all caused by mutations in the same gene
All misfolded proteins are immediately cleared by the immune system with no pathological consequences

The misfolded proteins share a tendency to form cross-β amyloid structures, and the oligomeric intermediates (rather than the mature fibrils) are often the most toxic species, disrupting membrane integrity and triggering inflammatory responses
Protein misfolding only occurs in neurons and never in other cell types
questions.explanation: Proteinopathies include Alzheimer's (Aβ, tau), Parkinson's (α-synuclein), Huntington's (huntingtin polyQ), ALS (SOD1, TDP-43, FUS), prion diseases (PrP), type 2 diabetes (IAPP/amylin), and systemic amyloidoses (transthyretin, lysozyme). The common feature is protein misfolding leading to β-rich aggregates. A critical insight is that soluble oligomeric intermediates (not the insoluble mature fibrils) are often the most cytotoxic species — they can permeabilize cell membranes (forming annular pore-like structures), trigger calcium influx, activate microglia (neuroinflammation), induce oxidative stress, and impair proteasomal and autophagic clearance. The cell has quality control mechanisms (ubiquitin-proteasome system, autophagy, chaperones, unfolded protein response) that become overwhelmed with aging. Current therapeutic strategies target oligomer formation, enhance clearance, or stabilize the native fold. Option A is wrong. Option B is wrong — clearance is overwhelmed. Option D is wrong — amyloidosis affects many tissues.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The Michaelis constant (Km) in enzyme kinetics represents:
options: The maximum rate of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction at infinite substrate concentration

The substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax, and it is an approximate measure of the enzyme's affinity for its substrate — a low Km indicates high affinity (the enzyme reaches half-maximal rate at lower substrate)
The concentration of enzyme needed to achieve maximum rate
The equilibrium constant for the overall reaction
questions.explanation: Km (Michaelis constant) is defined as the substrate concentration [S] at which the reaction velocity (v) equals half of the maximal velocity (Vmax/2). For a simple enzyme mechanism (E + S ⇌ ES → E + P), Km = (k₋₁ + k₂)/k₁, where k₁ is the rate constant for ES formation, k₋₁ for ES dissociation, and k₂ for product formation (kcat). When k₂ << k₋₁ (rapid equilibrium approximation), Km ≈ Kd (the dissociation constant), and Km directly measures substrate binding affinity. Lower Km means the enzyme reaches half-saturation at lower [S], indicating higher apparent affinity. Typical Km values range from ~1 μM (high affinity) to ~10 mM (low affinity). Km is a kinetic parameter, not a pure binding constant. The catalytic efficiency kcat/Km (also called the specificity constant) measures overall enzyme performance and is limited by diffusion (~10⁸-10⁹ M⁻¹s⁻¹). Option A defines Vmax. Option C is not a standard kinetic parameter. Option D describes Keq.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The reducing end of a polysaccharide is biologically and analytically significant because:
options: It is the end where new monomers are added during chain elongation in all polysaccharides
The reducing end is always capped with a phosphate group
All ends of polysaccharides are identical with no distinction between reducing and non-reducing ends

It contains a free anomeric carbon that can open to expose an aldehyde (or ketone) group capable of reducing Cu²⁺ ions — this is the basis of Benedict's test for reducing sugars and is the end from which glycogen phosphorylase initiates degradation
questions.explanation: In a polysaccharide chain, one end (the reducing end) has a free anomeric carbon (C-1 in aldoses) that is not involved in a glycosidic bond. This free anomeric carbon can undergo ring-opening to expose the aldehyde group, which can reduce mild oxidizing agents like Cu²⁺ (Benedict's reagent: blue → orange/red) or Ag⁺ (Tollens' reagent: silver mirror). The opposite end (non-reducing end) has its anomeric carbon locked in a glycosidic bond. In glycogen and starch, there is only ONE reducing end but many non-reducing ends (one per branch). Glycogen phosphorylase cleaves glucose-1-phosphate from non-reducing ends (not the reducing end), and glycogen synthase adds glucose to non-reducing ends. Having many non-reducing ends allows simultaneous degradation by multiple phosphorylase enzymes for rapid glucose mobilization. Option A incorrectly states new monomers are added at the reducing end. Option C is wrong. Option B is generally wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about enzyme regulation:
S1: Allosteric regulation involves binding of effector molecules at sites other than the active site, causing conformational changes that alter enzyme activity.
S2: Feedback inhibition typically involves the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibiting the first enzyme in the pathway, preventing wasteful overproduction.
S3: Covalent modification (e.g., phosphorylation by kinases, dephosphorylation by phosphatases) provides rapid, reversible regulation of enzyme activity.
S4: Proteolytic activation (e.g., zymogens like trypsinogen → trypsin) is freely reversible — active enzymes can be converted back to their zymogen forms.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Allosteric regulation is a fundamental mechanism where small molecule effectors bind to allosteric sites (regulatory sites distinct from the active site), causing conformational changes transmitted through the protein structure. Positive effectors (activators) stabilize the R (active) state; negative effectors (inhibitors) stabilize the T (inactive) state. S2 is TRUE: Feedback (end-product) inhibition is a common metabolic regulatory strategy. For example, isoleucine inhibits threonine deaminase (first enzyme in isoleucine biosynthesis). ATP inhibits PFK-1 (glycolysis). CTP inhibits ATCase (pyrimidine biosynthesis). S3 is TRUE: Phosphorylation by protein kinases and dephosphorylation by phosphatases provides rapid (<1 second), reversible regulation. The human genome encodes ~518 kinases and ~140 phosphatases, regulating thousands of proteins. S4 is FALSE: Proteolytic activation is IRREVERSIBLE. Once the proenzyme peptide bond is cleaved (e.g., trypsinogen → trypsin by removal of a hexapeptide), the enzyme cannot be converted back. New zymogen molecules must be synthesized.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the structure of biological membranes:
S1: Membrane lipid composition is asymmetric — the outer and inner leaflets have different phospholipid species, maintained by flippases, floppases, and scramblases.
S2: Integral membrane proteins span the bilayer with α-helical or β-barrel transmembrane domains, and their orientation is fixed (they do not flip between leaflets).
S3: Peripheral membrane proteins are loosely associated with the membrane surface through electrostatic interactions or lipid anchors and can be removed by high salt or pH changes.
S4: All membrane proteins are free to diffuse laterally without any restriction, as originally proposed in the fluid mosaic model.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Membrane leaflet asymmetry is actively maintained. In the plasma membrane: outer leaflet is enriched in phosphatidylcholine (PC) and sphingomyelin; inner leaflet is enriched in phosphatidylserine (PS) and phosphatidylethanolamine (PE). Flippases (P4-ATPases, ATP-dependent) move PS and PE inward; floppases (ABC transporters) move lipids outward; scramblases (Ca²⁺-activated) randomize distribution. PS exposure on the outer leaflet is an 'eat me' signal for apoptosis. S2 is TRUE: Integral proteins span the bilayer, typically via hydrophobic α-helices (~20 amino acids cross ~30 Å of the lipid core) or β-barrels (porins). Their topology is fixed during synthesis and they do NOT flip. S3 is TRUE: Peripheral proteins associate with the membrane surface and can be extracted by high salt (disrupting electrostatic interactions), high pH (deprotonation), or chelation of divalent cations. S4 is FALSE: Modern understanding shows that protein diffusion is restricted by cytoskeletal fences (actin cortex), lipid rafts, protein crowding, and extracellular matrix interactions.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy is used to estimate protein secondary structure. The following data shows mean residue ellipticity [θ] at specific wavelengths for three proteins:

| Wavelength (nm) | Protein P (deg·cm²/dmol) | Protein Q | Protein R |
|------------------|--------------------------|-----------|-----------|
| 208              | -33,000                  | -18,000   | -5,000    |
| 215              | -10,000                  | -22,000   | -3,000    |
| 222              | -30,000                  | -8,000    | -2,000    |

α-helical proteins show negative bands at 208 and 222 nm; β-sheet proteins show a negative band at 215-218 nm. Which structural assignment is most consistent with the data?
options: Protein P is β-sheet, Protein Q is α-helical, Protein R is disordered
All three proteins have identical secondary structure

Protein P is predominantly α-helical (strong negative bands at 208 and 222 nm), Protein Q is predominantly β-sheet (strongest negative band at 215 nm), and Protein R is largely disordered or has minimal regular secondary structure (weak CD signal at all wavelengths)
Protein R is the most structured because it has the smallest CD values
questions.explanation: CD spectroscopy measures the differential absorption of left and right circularly polarized light by chiral molecules. Each type of secondary structure produces a characteristic CD spectrum. α-helices show two negative bands at 208 nm and 222 nm and a positive band at 193 nm, with the 222 nm band being approximately 60-100% of the 208 nm band. Protein P fits this pattern perfectly: strong negative bands at both 208 (-33,000) and 222 (-30,000). β-sheets show a single negative band at 215-218 nm and a positive band at 195-200 nm. Protein Q has its most negative value at 215 nm (-22,000), consistent with β-sheet dominance. Disordered proteins show weak CD signals (near zero) at most wavelengths, with a slight negative band near 200 nm. Protein R has weak negative values at all wavelengths (-2,000 to -5,000), indicating minimal regular structure. Option A reverses P and Q. Option B is wrong. Option D confuses weak signal with structure.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
A nutritional study compares the caloric content of different macronutrients:

| Macronutrient | kcal/gram | Respiratory quotient (RQ = CO₂ produced / O₂ consumed) |
|---------------|-----------|----------------------------------------------------------|
| Carbohydrate  | 4.0       | 1.0                                                      |
| Protein       | 4.0       | 0.8                                                      |
| Fat           | 9.0       | 0.7                                                      |
| Alcohol       | 7.0       | 0.67                                                     |

A patient's respiratory quotient is measured at 0.85. What is the most likely metabolic substrate being oxidized?
options: Pure carbohydrate, because RQ of 1.0 is close to 0.85
Pure fat, because fat is always the preferred fuel

A mixture of carbohydrate and fat — the intermediate RQ value (between 1.0 for pure carbohydrate and 0.7 for pure fat) indicates approximately 50% of energy is derived from carbohydrate and 50% from fat oxidation
The patient is not metabolizing any substrate and is in a state of complete starvation
questions.explanation: The respiratory quotient (RQ = VCO₂/VO₂) reflects the metabolic fuel mix being oxidized. For pure carbohydrate: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O, RQ = 6/6 = 1.0. For pure fat (palmitate): C₁₆H₃₂O₂ + 23O₂ → 16CO₂ + 16H₂O, RQ = 16/23 = 0.70. An RQ of 0.85 is intermediate, indicating a mixed fuel source. Using linear interpolation: (0.85 - 0.70)/(1.0 - 0.70) = 0.15/0.30 = 0.50, indicating approximately 50% of calories from carbohydrate and 50% from fat. This is a typical resting RQ for a person on a mixed diet. During exercise, RQ rises toward 1.0 (more carbohydrate oxidation). During fasting, RQ drops toward 0.70 (fat oxidation dominates). RQ > 1.0 indicates net lipogenesis (converting carbohydrate to fat, which releases CO₂ without consuming O₂). Option A ignores the deviation from 1.0. Option B ignores the deviation from 0.7. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: To determine whether a protein's enzymatic activity requires its native three-dimensional structure (or whether a linear peptide fragment could suffice), a researcher should:
options: Simply measure the protein's molecular weight
Sequence the protein and predict activity from sequence alone
Test the protein's activity at only one temperature and conclude about structure dependence

Denature the protein completely with 8M urea or 6M guanidinium chloride, then test for enzymatic activity — if activity is abolished upon denaturation and recovered upon refolding (removing denaturant), this demonstrates that the native 3D structure is required for catalysis
questions.explanation: The most direct experiment to test whether native 3D structure is required for activity is Anfinsen-style denaturation/renaturation. (1) Measure native enzyme activity (positive control). (2) Denature completely with a strong chaotropic agent (8M urea or 6M guanidinium chloride) and, if necessary, reduce disulfide bonds (DTT). (3) Test for activity while denatured — if 3D structure is required, activity should be abolished. (4) Slowly remove denaturant (dialysis or dilution) to allow refolding. (5) Test activity again — if it recovers, this confirms the native fold is both necessary and sufficient. Additional controls: test with protease-digested fragments (to rule out that a small linear peptide retains activity), and use CD spectroscopy to verify structural changes. For some enzymes, active-site peptides do retain minimal activity, but typically orders of magnitude lower than the native enzyme. Option A provides no activity information. Option C is insufficient. Option B cannot experimentally prove structure-activity relationship.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that a specific glycosylation site (Asn-297) on an antibody is required for its ability to activate complement. To test this, she should:
options: Delete the entire antibody gene and observe the effect on complement activation

Mutate Asn-297 to Gln (N297Q) by site-directed mutagenesis — this eliminates the glycosylation sequon while maintaining similar amino acid size, then compare complement activation between wild-type and N297Q mutant antibodies
Add excess free sugars to the assay to competitively inhibit glycosylation-dependent binding
Measure the antibody's antigen-binding activity instead of complement activation
questions.explanation: The N297Q mutation is the standard approach for testing glycosylation-dependent functions of antibodies. The rationale: (1) Asn (N) is the attachment point for N-linked glycosylation at the sequon Asn-X-Ser/Thr. (2) Glutamine (Q) is the most conservative substitution — it is nearly identical in size and shape to asparagine (both are amides) but cannot accept an N-glycan because the sequon is disrupted. (3) The N297Q antibody retains its overall fold, antigen-binding ability, and pharmacokinetics but lacks the Fc glycan at position 297. (4) If complement activation is lost in the N297Q mutant, this directly demonstrates that the Asn-297 glycan is required. This experiment has been performed extensively: aglycosylated IgG1 cannot bind FcγRs or activate complement, proving the Fc glycan is essential for effector functions. Enzymatic deglycosylation with PNGase F provides confirmatory evidence. Option A is too drastic. Option C is not specific enough. Option D measures the wrong function.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: To determine whether a newly discovered carbohydrate-binding protein (lectin) on the surface of immune cells mediates the recognition of a specific pathogen, a researcher should:
options: Knock out or block the lectin (using gene knockout, siRNA knockdown, or blocking antibodies), then compare pathogen binding and phagocytosis between lectin-deficient and wild-type cells — additionally, compete with free carbohydrate ligand to demonstrate sugar-dependent binding
Simply observe that immune cells interact with the pathogen and conclude the lectin is involved
Measure the immune cell's DNA content before and after pathogen exposure
Stain the immune cells with a non-specific dye and observe under a microscope
questions.explanation: Demonstrating that a specific lectin mediates pathogen recognition requires multiple lines of evidence: (1) Loss-of-function: Generate lectin-knockout cells (CRISPR) or knockdown (siRNA), or block with specific anti-lectin antibodies. If pathogen binding and phagocytosis are reduced, the lectin is involved. (2) Gain-of-function: Express the lectin in cells that normally don't have it and test whether they acquire pathogen-binding ability. (3) Competition: Add free carbohydrate (the lectin's sugar ligand) to the assay. If it competitively inhibits pathogen binding in a dose-dependent manner, this confirms sugar-dependent recognition. (4) Binding assays: Demonstrate direct interaction between purified lectin and pathogen surface glycans using SPR (surface plasmon resonance), ITC (isothermal titration calorimetry), or glycan array screening. (5) In vivo: Test lectin-knockout mice for susceptibility to the pathogen. Option B provides correlation, not causation. Option C is irrelevant. Option D is non-specific.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Saponification is the base-catalyzed hydrolysis of triacylglycerols. When a fat is treated with NaOH, the products are:
options: Glycerol and fatty acid sodium salts (soap molecules) — the sodium salts of fatty acids are amphipathic, with a hydrophilic carboxylate head and hydrophobic hydrocarbon tail, enabling them to emulsify grease in water
Fatty acids and glycerol only
Amino acids and glucose
Phospholipids and cholesterol
questions.explanation: Saponification (Latin: sapo = soap) is the alkaline hydrolysis of ester bonds in fats/oils. NaOH (or KOH) cleaves the three ester bonds linking fatty acids to glycerol, producing glycerol and three molecules of fatty acid sodium salts (soap). The reaction is: fat + 3NaOH → glycerol + 3RCOO⁻Na⁺. The resulting soap molecules are amphipathic: the carboxylate group (COO⁻Na⁺) is hydrophilic, while the long hydrocarbon chain (C12-C18) is hydrophobic. In water, soap molecules form micelles with hydrophobic cores that can dissolve (emulsify) grease and oil. This is why soap cleans — it disperses hydrophobic dirt into aqueous solution. Hard water (containing Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺) causes soap scum because calcium/magnesium fatty acid salts are insoluble. Detergents (synthetic surfactants) were developed to overcome this limitation. Option B describes acid hydrolysis products. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The central dogma of molecular biology (DNA → RNA → protein) relies on specific macromolecular interactions. Which nucleic acid serves as the physical adapter between the genetic code (mRNA) and the amino acid sequence of proteins?
options: Ribosomal RNA (rRNA), which catalyzes peptide bond formation
Small nuclear RNA (snRNA), which participates in mRNA splicing

Transfer RNA (tRNA), which has an anticodon that base-pairs with mRNA codons at one end and carries the corresponding amino acid at its 3' CCA end, physically linking nucleotide sequence information to amino acid identity
Messenger RNA (mRNA), which directly assembles amino acids without any adapter
questions.explanation: Transfer RNA is the adapter molecule proposed by Francis Crick in his 1958 'adapter hypothesis.' Each tRNA has two critical functional sites: (1) the anticodon loop (3 nucleotides that base-pair with a complementary mRNA codon) and (2) the 3' acceptor stem ending in the universal CCA sequence, where the cognate amino acid is covalently attached by an aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase via an ester bond. The tRNA thus physically bridges the nucleic acid world (codon recognition) and the protein world (amino acid delivery). There are ~45 different tRNAs in human cells, covering all 61 sense codons through wobble base pairing at the third position. The L-shaped 3D structure of tRNA (cloverleaf secondary structure with tertiary interactions creating an L) positions the anticodon and amino acid ~76 Å apart. Option A describes the ribosome's catalytic role. Option B describes splicing. Option D ignores the essential adapter.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Epimers are sugars that differ at only one chiral center. Mannose is the C-2 epimer of glucose. The biological significance of epimerization reactions is that:
options: Epimers are always interchangeable in biological systems because they are essentially the same sugar

Epimerases catalyze the interconversion of sugars at specific chiral centers, enabling cells to convert abundant sugars to rarer ones needed for glycoprotein and glycolipid synthesis — for example, UDP-glucose 4-epimerase converts UDP-glucose to UDP-galactose
Epimerization only occurs during chemical synthesis and never in biological systems
Epimers always have identical biological activities because the structural difference is too small to matter
questions.explanation: Epimerases are enzymes that catalyze the inversion of configuration at a single stereocenter in sugar molecules. UDP-glucose 4-epimerase (GALE) is a key example: it interconverts UDP-glucose and UDP-galactose by oxidation and reduction at C-4 using NAD⁺ as a cofactor. This reaction is essential because galactose is needed for glycoprotein synthesis, lactose production (in mammary glands), and glycolipid synthesis, but galactose may not always be available from the diet. Other important epimerases include: UDP-N-acetylglucosamine 2-epimerase (converts UDP-GlcNAc to UDP-ManNAc, a precursor for sialic acid synthesis) and UDP-xylose 4-epimerase. Deficiency of GALE causes a form of galactosemia. Option A is wrong — epimers are recognized differently by enzymes. Option C is wrong — epimerases are common in metabolism. Option D is wrong — the stereochemical difference has profound biological consequences.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The 310 helix and π-helix are alternative helical conformations to the α-helix in proteins. The 310 helix differs from the α-helix in that:
options: The 310 helix is left-handed while the α-helix is right-handed

The 310 helix has i→i+3 hydrogen bonds (vs i→i+4 in α-helix), 3 residues per turn (vs 3.6), and a narrower diameter, making it more tightly wound but less stable due to poorer hydrogen bond geometry — it is commonly found at the ends of α-helices
The 310 helix is the most common helical form in proteins, much more abundant than the α-helix
The 310 helix contains no hydrogen bonds and is stabilized entirely by hydrophobic interactions
questions.explanation: The 310 helix has hydrogen bonds between residue i C=O and residue i+3 N-H (compared to i+4 in α-helix), resulting in 3.0 residues per turn and 10 atoms in the hydrogen-bonded ring (hence '310'). The helix is narrower (diameter ~1.9 Å rise per residue vs 1.5 Å for α-helix) and more tightly wound. The hydrogen bonds in a 310 helix are less linear (~160° vs ~170° in α-helix), making them weaker. 310 helices are less stable and much less common than α-helices — they typically occur as short segments (1-2 turns) at the N- or C-terminal ends of α-helices, or in tight turns. The π-helix has i→i+5 hydrogen bonds, 4.4 residues per turn, and is wider than the α-helix — it is even rarer, found in <2% of helical residues, but occurs in some enzyme active sites. Option A is wrong — both are right-handed. Option C reverses the abundance. Option D is wrong — 310 helices have hydrogen bonds.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: GPI (glycosylphosphatidylinositol) anchors attach certain proteins to the outer leaflet of the cell membrane. The structure of a GPI anchor includes:
options: A complex glycan core (containing glucosamine, mannose, and ethanolamine phosphate) linked to the C-terminus of the protein via an amide bond to ethanolamine, with the lipid moiety (phosphatidylinositol) embedded in the outer membrane leaflet
A simple prenyl lipid group attached directly to the protein's N-terminus
A transmembrane α-helix that spans the lipid bilayer
A direct covalent bond between the protein's side chains and membrane cholesterol
questions.explanation: GPI anchors are complex glycolipids that tether proteins to the extracellular face of the plasma membrane. The structure (from protein to membrane) consists of: (1) an amide bond between the protein's C-terminal α-carboxyl and the amino group of ethanolamine; (2) ethanolamine linked via phosphoester to a core glycan containing mannose residues; (3) the core glycan linked to glucosamine (GlcN); (4) GlcN linked to inositol of phosphatidylinositol (PI); (5) PI embedded in the outer membrane leaflet via its fatty acid chains. GPI-anchored proteins include: alkaline phosphatase, 5'-nucleotidase, acetylcholinesterase, CD55 (DAF), CD59, T. brucei VSG (variant surface glycoprotein), and prion protein (PrPᶜ). GPI anchors are enriched in lipid rafts. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is caused by defective GPI synthesis (mutation in PIGA gene), leading to complement-mediated hemolysis. Option B describes prenylation. Option C describes integral membrane proteins. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The isoelectric point (pI) of a protein is the pH at which:
options: The protein is most soluble in aqueous solution
The protein is completely denatured
All amino acid residues are fully protonated

The protein has zero net charge — the sum of all positive charges (protonated amines, Lys, Arg, His) equals the sum of all negative charges (deprotonated carboxylates, Asp, Glu, Cys, Tyr), and the protein does not migrate in an electric field
questions.explanation: The isoelectric point (pI) is the pH at which a protein's net charge is exactly zero. At this pH, positive charges (from protonated amino groups: N-terminus, Lys ε-amino, Arg guanidinium, His imidazolium) exactly balance negative charges (from deprotonated groups: C-terminus, Asp/Glu carboxylates, Cys thiolates, Tyr phenolates). At the pI, the protein does not migrate in an electric field (this is the basis of isoelectric focusing, a high-resolution protein separation technique). Below the pI, the protein has net positive charge and migrates toward the cathode. Above the pI, it has net negative charge and migrates toward the anode. Proteins are typically LEAST soluble at their pI because they lack net charge to repel neighboring protein molecules, promoting aggregation. For example: pepsin (pI ~1), albumin (pI ~4.9), hemoglobin (pI ~6.8), lysozyme (pI ~11). Option A is the opposite. Option C would be at very low pH. Option B is unrelated.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Cellulose microfibrils in plant cell walls are arranged in a cross-linked network embedded in a matrix of hemicellulose and pectin. This composite structure is analogous to:
options: Reinforced concrete, where cellulose microfibrils act as the steel rebar (providing tensile strength) and the hemicellulose-pectin matrix acts as the concrete (providing compression resistance and binding the fibers together)
A solution of dissolved sugars in water
A single crystal of pure glucose
A lipid bilayer membrane
questions.explanation: The plant cell wall is a remarkable composite material with properties analogous to engineered composites. Cellulose microfibrils (bundles of ~36 parallel β-1,4-glucan chains held by hydrogen bonds) provide extraordinary tensile strength (~130 GPa Young's modulus, comparable to Kevlar). These microfibrils are embedded in a matrix of: (1) hemicelluloses (branched polysaccharides like xyloglucan that hydrogen-bond to cellulose surfaces, cross-linking microfibrils); (2) pectins (negatively charged polysaccharides like homogalacturonan that form hydrated gels, providing resistance to compression); (3) in secondary cell walls, lignin (a phenylpropanoid polymer that provides additional rigidity and water resistance). This fiber-matrix architecture functions like reinforced concrete: cellulose = steel rebar (tensile resistance), matrix = concrete (compression resistance). The orientation of cellulose microfibrils determines the direction of cell expansion (cells elongate perpendicular to microfibril orientation). Option B is wrong. Option C is wrong. Option D is structurally unrelated.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The triplet code in mRNA is read by the ribosome without any gaps or overlaps. This 'reading frame' property means that:
options: Any insertion or deletion of nucleotides that is not a multiple of 3 causes a frameshift mutation, changing the reading frame and altering all downstream amino acids — this typically results in a non-functional protein with a premature stop codon
The genetic code can be read in all three frames simultaneously on one mRNA
Frameshift mutations have no effect on protein sequence because the code is degenerate
Only the first codon in an mRNA determines the entire protein sequence
questions.explanation: The genetic code is read in non-overlapping triplets (codons) starting from the AUG start codon, which establishes the reading frame. Any insertion or deletion of nucleotides that is not a multiple of 3 (e.g., +1, +2, -1, -2 bases) shifts the reading frame from that point onward, completely changing the amino acid sequence downstream of the mutation. Because 3 of 64 codons are stop codons (UAA, UAG, UGA), a random reading frame will encounter a premature stop codon approximately every 64/3 ≈ 21 codons on average, producing a truncated, usually nonfunctional protein. Frameshift mutations are generally more severe than missense mutations because they alter many amino acids rather than just one. Insertions or deletions of exactly 3 (or multiples of 3) nucleotides add or remove amino acids without disrupting the reading frame, often producing less severe effects. Option B is wrong — only one frame is used. Option C is wrong — frameshifts are devastating. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Enzyme cofactors and coenzymes are essential for many enzymatic reactions. The distinction between a cofactor and a coenzyme is:
options: Cofactors are inorganic metal ions (Zn²⁺, Mg²⁺, Fe²⁺/³⁺, Cu²⁺, Mn²⁺) or small organic molecules (coenzymes) that are required for enzyme activity — coenzymes are specifically organic molecules (often derived from vitamins) that serve as transient carriers of specific functional groups or electrons during catalysis
There is no difference — both terms are synonymous
Cofactors are always covalently bound while coenzymes are never bound to enzymes
Coenzymes are large proteins while cofactors are small molecules
questions.explanation: Cofactors are non-protein molecules required for enzyme activity. They are broadly classified as: (1) Metal ion cofactors: inorganic ions like Zn²⁺ (carbonic anhydrase, carboxypeptidase), Mg²⁺ (kinases, DNA polymerase), Fe²⁺/Fe³⁺ (cytochromes, catalase), Cu²⁺ (cytochrome c oxidase), Mn²⁺ (superoxide dismutase). (2) Coenzymes: organic molecules that serve as group-transfer agents — NAD⁺/NADH (hydride transfer, from niacin/vitamin B3), FAD/FADH₂ (electron transfer, from riboflavin/B2), CoA (acyl transfer, from pantothenic acid/B5), TPP (decarboxylation, from thiamine/B1), PLP (amino group transfer, from pyridoxine/B6), biotin (carboxylation, vitamin B7), THF (one-carbon transfer, from folate). Tightly bound coenzymes are called prosthetic groups (e.g., FAD in succinate dehydrogenase). The holoenzyme = apoenzyme + cofactor/coenzyme. Option B is incorrect. Option C oversimplifies. Option D reverses definitions.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes are collectively called eicosanoids. They are synthesized from:
options: Cholesterol by cytochrome P450 enzymes
Amino acids through transamination
Glucose through glycolysis

Arachidonic acid (20:4 ω-6), a 20-carbon polyunsaturated fatty acid released from membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A₂ — cyclooxygenase (COX) produces prostaglandins and thromboxanes, while lipoxygenase produces leukotrienes
questions.explanation: Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid mediators derived from 20-carbon (eicosa = 20) polyunsaturated fatty acids, primarily arachidonic acid (20:4, Δ5,8,11,14, an ω-6 fatty acid). The biosynthetic pathway begins with phospholipase A₂ (PLA₂), which releases arachidonic acid from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids. The free arachidonic acid is then metabolized by: (1) Cyclooxygenase-1/2 (COX-1, COX-2): produces prostaglandins (PGE₂, PGI₂ prostacyclin) and thromboxanes (TXA₂). NSAIDs like aspirin and ibuprofen inhibit COX enzymes. (2) 5-Lipoxygenase (5-LOX): produces leukotrienes (LTB₄, LTC₄, LTD₄), which mediate inflammation and bronchoconstriction (asthma). (3) Cytochrome P450 epoxygenases: produce epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs). Eicosanoids are local signaling molecules (paracrines/autocrines) with diverse roles in inflammation, pain, fever, blood clotting, blood pressure regulation, and reproduction. Option A describes steroid hormone synthesis. Option C is wrong. Option B is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: X-ray crystallography has been the primary method for determining atomic-resolution protein structures. The method requires:
options: Dissolving the protein in an organic solvent and measuring light refraction
Measuring the mass of the protein using mass spectrometry
Simply photographing the protein under a light microscope at high magnification

Growing a well-ordered protein crystal, exposing it to an intense X-ray beam, measuring the diffraction pattern (intensity and position of scattered X-rays), solving the 'phase problem,' and computing an electron density map that reveals the positions of individual atoms
questions.explanation: X-ray crystallography (pioneered by Max Perutz and John Kendrew for myoglobin/hemoglobin, 1958-1962 Nobel Prize) requires: (1) Protein crystallization: growing highly ordered 3D crystals by slowly precipitating purified protein from solution (vapor diffusion, hanging/sitting drop methods). (2) X-ray diffraction: exposing the crystal to a monochromatic X-ray beam (synchrotron radiation, λ ~1 Å). The regular arrangement of molecules in the crystal diffracts X-rays, producing a pattern of spots on a detector. (3) Data processing: measuring spot intensities and positions to determine structure factor amplitudes. (4) Phase determination: solving the 'phase problem' (phases cannot be measured directly) using molecular replacement, isomorphous replacement (heavy atom derivatives), or anomalous scattering (selenomethionine). (5) Electron density map: combining amplitudes and phases via Fourier transform to compute a 3D electron density map. (6) Model building and refinement. Resolution is typically 1.5-3.0 Å. Cryo-EM has recently become competitive. Option A is wrong. Option C cannot achieve atomic resolution. Option B measures mass, not structure.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Starch and glycogen both serve as glucose storage polymers but have different structural features adapted to their biological roles. Amylose (a component of starch) differs from amylopectin in that:
options: Amylose is an essentially unbranched polymer of α-1,4-linked glucose that forms a helical coil capable of binding iodine molecules in its hydrophobic interior (producing a blue-black color), while amylopectin has both α-1,4 and α-1,6 linkages creating a branched structure that binds less iodine (producing a red-brown color)
Amylose is branched while amylopectin is linear
Amylose uses β-1,4 linkages while amylopectin uses α-1,4 linkages
Amylose is found only in animals while amylopectin is found only in plants
questions.explanation: Starch consists of two polysaccharide components: amylose (typically 20-30% of starch) and amylopectin (70-80%). Amylose is essentially unbranched (very rare α-1,6 branch points), consisting of α-1,4-linked glucose residues. The helical shape of amylose (6 glucose units per turn with a hydrophobic interior) can trap iodine molecules (I₃⁻ and I₅⁻ polyiodide chains) within its coil, producing the characteristic blue-black color of the starch-iodine test. Amylopectin has the same α-1,4 backbone but with α-1,6 branch points every 24-30 residues. The branched structure cannot form the long continuous helix needed for efficient iodine binding, producing only a red-brown color with iodine. The starch-iodine test is a classic qualitative test in biochemistry labs. Waxy starches (nearly 100% amylopectin) give a red-brown color, while high-amylose starches give a deep blue. Option B reverses the structures. Option C is wrong — both use α-linkages. Option D is wrong — both are plant polymers.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The concept of a protein's 'folding funnel' in the energy landscape theory describes:
options: A flat energy surface where all conformations are equally stable
An energy landscape where the native state is at the highest energy level
A single narrow pathway that all protein molecules must follow identically during folding

A funnel-shaped free energy landscape where unfolded conformations (high entropy, high energy, top of funnel) progressively descend toward the native state (low entropy, low energy, bottom of funnel) through increasingly native-like intermediate states, with the width representing conformational entropy and depth representing energetic stabilization
questions.explanation: The energy landscape theory (Ken Dill, Peter Wolynes, Jose Onuchic) revolutionized understanding of protein folding. Rather than a single defined pathway (old view), proteins fold through a funnel-shaped energy landscape. The top of the funnel is broad, representing the vast conformational space of unfolded states (high entropy, high energy). As the protein folds, it descends the funnel through progressively more native-like states — entropy decreases (fewer conformations) while enthalpy decreases (more native contacts formed). The native state sits at the bottom of the funnel (minimal energy, minimal entropy). The funnel is 'rough' with local energy minima that can temporarily trap the protein (kinetic traps = misfolded intermediates). Different protein molecules can take different paths down the funnel (multiple folding routes), converging on the same native state. This explains Levinthal's paradox: the funnel biases the search, and most of conformational space is never explored. Option A contradicts the concept. Option C is the old pathway view. Option B reverses the energy relationship.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Non-reducing sugars like sucrose and trehalose have special biological properties. Trehalose (α,α-1,1-linked glucose disaccharide) is used as a stress protectant in many organisms because:
options: It provides more energy per gram than any other sugar

It stabilizes proteins and membranes during desiccation by replacing water molecules in hydrogen bonding networks (the 'water replacement' hypothesis), and it forms a glassy matrix that immobilizes biomolecules and prevents denaturation during anhydrobiosis
It is toxic to all organisms and kills competitors
It serves exclusively as a signaling molecule with no protective function
questions.explanation: Trehalose (α-D-glucopyranosyl α-D-glucopyranoside) is a non-reducing disaccharide found at high concentrations in organisms that survive extreme desiccation (anhydrobiosis): tardigrades, brine shrimp (Artemia), resurrection plants, yeast, and many insects. During drying, trehalose protects biomolecules through two complementary mechanisms: (1) Water replacement hypothesis: trehalose's hydroxyl groups form hydrogen bonds with polar groups on proteins and phospholipid head groups, replacing the hydrogen bonds normally provided by water and maintaining native structure. (2) Vitrification: trehalose forms a glassy (amorphous solid) matrix upon drying (Tg ~115°C), which immobilizes biomolecules in their native conformations and prevents aggregation, crystallization of membrane lipids, and protein denaturation. Upon rehydration, the glass dissolves and biomolecules resume normal function. Trehalose is used commercially for protein and vaccine stabilization. Option A is wrong about energy content. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about amino acid properties:
S1: The 20 standard amino acids can be classified by their side chain properties: nonpolar/hydrophobic (Ala, Val, Leu, Ile, Pro, Phe, Trp, Met), polar uncharged (Ser, Thr, Cys, Tyr, Asn, Gln), positively charged at pH 7 (Lys, Arg, His), and negatively charged at pH 7 (Asp, Glu).
S2: Proline is unique because its side chain forms a covalent bond with the backbone nitrogen, creating a cyclic structure that introduces rigid kinks and is found frequently in turns and in the collagen helix.
S3: Glycine is the only amino acid without a chiral center (its α-carbon has two hydrogen substituents), making it optically inactive.
S4: All 20 standard amino acids absorb visible light (400-700 nm), which is why proteins appear colored.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: This is the standard classification. At physiological pH (7.4): Lys (pKa ~10.5), Arg (pKa ~12.5), and His (pKa ~6.0, partially protonated) are positively charged. Asp (pKa ~3.65) and Glu (pKa ~4.25) are negatively charged. The hydrophobic amino acids have nonpolar side chains that tend to be buried in protein interiors. S2 is TRUE: Proline's cyclic pyrrolidine ring includes the backbone nitrogen, fixing the φ angle to approximately -63° and eliminating the N-H hydrogen bond donor. This rigidity introduces kinks in α-helices (proline is a 'helix breaker') and is common in turns, loops, and the polyproline II helix of collagen. S3 is TRUE: Glycine (H-Cα-NH₂-COOH) has two hydrogen atoms on its α-carbon, making it achiral. All other standard amino acids have four different substituents on Cα (R, H, NH₂, COOH) and are chiral. S4 is FALSE: Most proteins are colorless because amino acids absorb in the UV range (aromatic amino acids at 260-280 nm, peptide bonds at ~220 nm), not visible light. Colored proteins (hemoglobin, cytochromes, chlorophyll-binding proteins) owe their color to non-amino acid prosthetic groups.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about nucleotide structure and function:
S1: Nucleotides consist of three components: a nitrogenous base (purine or pyrimidine), a pentose sugar (ribose or deoxyribose), and one to three phosphate groups.
S2: ATP's primary role as an energy currency is due to the high-energy phosphoanhydride bonds between its phosphate groups, with hydrolysis of the γ-phosphate yielding ΔG°' ≈ -30.5 kJ/mol.
S3: cAMP (3',5'-cyclic AMP) is a second messenger formed from ATP by adenylyl cyclase, and it activates protein kinase A in signal transduction cascades.
S4: NAD⁺ and FAD are nucleotide-derived coenzymes, but they function primarily as structural components of the cell wall rather than as electron carriers in metabolism.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Nucleotides have three components: (1) a nitrogenous base (purines: adenine, guanine — two rings; pyrimidines: cytosine, thymine/uracil — one ring); (2) a pentose sugar (ribose in RNA, 2'-deoxyribose in DNA); (3) 1-3 phosphate groups (NMP, NDP, NTP). Nucleosides lack the phosphate group. S2 is TRUE: ATP has two phosphoanhydride bonds (α-β and β-γ). Hydrolysis of the γ-phosphate (ATP → ADP + Pi) releases ΔG°' ≈ -30.5 kJ/mol due to charge repulsion relief, resonance stabilization of products, increased entropy, and favorable hydration. S3 is TRUE: Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP to 3',5'-cyclic AMP (cAMP) by forming an intramolecular phosphoester. cAMP binds the regulatory subunits of protein kinase A (PKA), releasing and activating the catalytic subunits. This is a major signaling pathway downstream of G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs). S4 is FALSE: NAD⁺/NADH and FAD/FADH₂ are critical electron carriers in metabolism (dehydrogenase reactions, electron transport chain), not structural components.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
A student separates a mixture of amino acids using paper electrophoresis at pH 6.0. The amino acids and their pI values are:

| Amino acid | pI    |
|------------|-------|
| Aspartate  | 2.77  |
| Alanine    | 6.02  |
| Lysine     | 9.74  |
| Histidine  | 7.59  |

What is the predicted order of migration from cathode (negative electrode) to anode (positive electrode)?
options: Lysine → Histidine → Alanine → Aspartate, because at pH 6.0: Lys (pI 9.74, net positive charge) and His (pI 7.59, net positive charge) migrate toward the cathode, Ala (pI 6.02, nearly neutral) stays near the origin, and Asp (pI 2.77, net negative charge) migrates toward the anode
All amino acids migrate equally because they all have the same charge at pH 6.0
Aspartate migrates fastest toward the cathode because it has the lowest pI
None of the amino acids migrate because electrophoresis does not work with amino acids
questions.explanation: At pH 6.0, the charge of each amino acid depends on the relationship between pH and pI. If pH < pI, the amino acid has a net positive charge (migrates toward cathode/negative electrode). If pH > pI, it has a net negative charge (migrates toward anode/positive electrode). If pH = pI, it is neutral. At pH 6.0: Lysine (pI 9.74): pH << pI, strongly positive, migrates toward cathode. Histidine (pI 7.59): pH < pI, moderately positive, migrates toward cathode (less than Lys). Alanine (pI 6.02): pH ≈ pI, essentially neutral, stays near origin. Aspartate (pI 2.77): pH >> pI, strongly negative, migrates toward anode. Therefore, from cathode to anode: Lysine → Histidine → Alanine (origin) → Aspartate. The speed of migration depends on the magnitude of the net charge and the molecular size. Option B is wrong — charges differ. Option C reverses the direction for Asp. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
An enzyme kinetics experiment yields the following data for reaction velocity at different substrate concentrations:

| [S] (mM) | v₀ (μmol/min) |
|----------|----------------|
| 0.1      | 2.5            |
| 0.2      | 4.5            |
| 0.5      | 8.3            |
| 1.0      | 11.1           |
| 2.0      | 13.3           |
| 5.0      | 15.2           |
| 10.0     | 16.0           |

Estimate Km and Vmax for this enzyme.
options: Km ≈ 10 mM, Vmax ≈ 2.5 μmol/min
The data does not follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics and Km cannot be estimated
Km ≈ 5.0 mM, Vmax ≈ 100 μmol/min
Km ≈ 0.5 mM, Vmax ≈ 16.7 μmol/min — at [S] = Km, v₀ should equal Vmax/2 ≈ 8.3, which matches the data point at [S] = 0.5 mM
questions.explanation: To estimate Km and Vmax from a v₀ vs [S] data set: Vmax is the asymptotic maximum velocity approached at very high [S]. The data shows v₀ approaching ~16-17 μmol/min at [S] = 10 mM. Estimating Vmax ≈ 16.7 μmol/min. Km is defined as the [S] at which v₀ = Vmax/2 = 16.7/2 ≈ 8.3 μmol/min. Looking at the data, v₀ = 8.3 μmol/min occurs at [S] = 0.5 mM. Therefore Km ≈ 0.5 mM. A Lineweaver-Burk plot (1/v₀ vs 1/[S]) could provide more precise values: y-intercept = 1/Vmax, x-intercept = -1/Km. More accurate methods include Eadie-Hofstee (v₀ vs v₀/[S]) and Hanes-Woolf ([S]/v₀ vs [S]) plots, or nonlinear regression fitting to the Michaelis-Menten equation v₀ = Vmax[S]/(Km + [S]). Option A gives wrong values. Option C vastly overestimates Vmax. Option B is wrong — the data follows typical Michaelis-Menten saturation kinetics.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: SDS-PAGE analysis of a purified protein shows a single band at approximately 55 kDa under denaturing conditions. Size-exclusion chromatography under native conditions gives an estimated molecular weight of 220 kDa. What can be concluded about the protein's quaternary structure?
options: The protein is a monomer that runs anomalously on SEC
SDS-PAGE and SEC data are incompatible and one must be wrong
The protein is a dimer because 55 × 2 = 110 kDa is close to 220 kDa
The protein is likely a homotetramer (4 identical 55 kDa subunits = 220 kDa), since SDS-PAGE shows only one band (one type of subunit) and native size is 4× the subunit mass
questions.explanation: Comparing denatured MW (from SDS-PAGE) with native MW (from SEC) reveals quaternary structure. SDS-PAGE denatures and dissociates all subunits, giving individual subunit mass: single band at 55 kDa indicates one type of subunit. SEC under native conditions measures the intact complex: 220 kDa. Ratio: 220/55 = 4.0, indicating a tetramer. Since only one band appears on SDS-PAGE, all four subunits are identical, making this a homotetramer (α₄). Examples of homotetramers include lactate dehydrogenase (~140 kDa, 4 × 35 kDa), β-galactosidase (~465 kDa, 4 × 116 kDa), and p53 (~172 kDa, 4 × 43 kDa). If there were two bands on SDS-PAGE (e.g., 55 kDa and 25 kDa), a heteromeric complex (e.g., α₂β₂) would be considered. Cross-linking experiments could further confirm the tetramer. Option A ignores the 4× ratio. Option C miscalculates (55×2=110, not 220). Option B falsely dismisses valid data.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: To determine the complete disulfide bond pattern (which cysteines are paired) in a protein with 6 cysteine residues (3 disulfide bonds), a researcher should:
options: Digest the native (non-reduced) protein with a protease under non-reducing conditions, separate the resulting peptide fragments (which may be disulfide-linked), identify the peptides by mass spectrometry, and determine which cysteine-containing peptides are linked — comparing to the reduced and alkylated digest reveals the specific Cys-Cys pairings
Simply count the number of cysteines and divide by 2 to determine the number of bonds
Denature the protein with SDS and measure the molecular weight by gel electrophoresis
Simply predict the disulfide bonds from the amino acid sequence without any experimental evidence
questions.explanation: Determining disulfide bond connectivity requires maintaining the native disulfide bonds during analysis. The standard approach: (1) Digest the native (oxidized) protein with a protease (trypsin, chymotrypsin, pepsin) under non-reducing conditions. Disulfide bonds remain intact, linking pairs of peptides. (2) Analyze the peptide mixture by LC-MS/MS. Disulfide-linked peptides have masses equal to the sum of the individual peptide masses minus 2 Da (loss of 2H during disulfide formation). (3) Fragment the disulfide-linked peptides by MS/MS to identify the specific residues involved. (4) Compare with a reduced/alkylated digest (where all disulfides are broken and cysteines are modified) to identify which peptides were linked. For a protein with 6 Cys and 3 disulfide bonds, there are 15 possible pairings (15 = 5×3×1), and the experiment identifies the correct one. Diagonal electrophoresis is an alternative approach. Option B determines number but not connectivity. Option C measures mass, not disulfide pattern. Option D is unreliable — sequence-based prediction has limited accuracy.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: A pharmaceutical company wants to test whether a new drug inhibits an enzyme through competitive or noncompetitive inhibition. The most definitive approach is to:
options: Simply measure enzyme activity with and without the drug at a single substrate concentration
Determine the drug's chemical formula and predict the inhibition type from its structure alone

Measure enzyme kinetics (v₀ vs [S]) at multiple inhibitor concentrations to generate a family of Michaelis-Menten curves, and analyze using Lineweaver-Burk double-reciprocal plots — competitive inhibition shows lines converging at the y-axis (same Vmax, different Km), while noncompetitive inhibition shows lines converging at the x-axis (same Km, different Vmax)
Test the drug's effect on a completely different enzyme and extrapolate the results
questions.explanation: Distinguishing competitive from noncompetitive inhibition requires measuring complete kinetic curves at multiple inhibitor concentrations. Method: (1) Measure v₀ at 7-10 different [S] values, with at least 3 different [inhibitor] concentrations plus uninhibited control. (2) Fit data to Michaelis-Menten equation or plot as Lineweaver-Burk (1/v₀ vs 1/[S]). Competitive inhibition: apparent Km increases (more substrate needed for half-Vmax) but Vmax is unchanged. LB plot: lines intersect at the y-axis. Noncompetitive inhibition: apparent Vmax decreases but Km is unchanged. LB plot: lines intersect at the x-axis. Uncompetitive inhibition: both Km and Vmax decrease proportionally. LB plot: parallel lines. Modern approaches use nonlinear regression fitting to appropriate inhibition models with statistical comparison (AIC, F-test). Ki (inhibition constant) is extracted from secondary plots. Option A provides insufficient data for classification. Option B ignores the need for empirical data. Option D is not valid.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: A researcher discovers a protein that appears to have no enzymatic activity but forms large aggregates in vitro. To determine whether these aggregates are amyloid fibrils (associated with disease) or functional amyloid (beneficial aggregates found in some organisms), she should:
options: Assume all protein aggregates are pathological and harmful
Test the protein's DNA-binding ability to classify its aggregation state
Simply measure the protein's molecular weight to determine if it is amyloid

Test for Congo red birefringence (apple-green under polarized light), ThT fluorescence, X-ray fiber diffraction (cross-β pattern at 4.7 Å), and determine whether the aggregation serves a biological function (biofilm formation, hormone storage, melanin polymerization) — functional amyloids are typically tightly regulated and reversible, while pathological amyloids are uncontrolled
questions.explanation: Distinguishing functional from pathological amyloid requires both structural characterization and biological context. Structural tests: (1) Congo red staining (binds amyloid, shows apple-green birefringence under crossed polarizers); (2) Thioflavin T (ThT) fluorescence (increased quantum yield upon binding to cross-β structure); (3) X-ray fiber diffraction (characteristic cross-β pattern: 4.7 Å meridional reflection from inter-strand spacing, 10-12 Å equatorial reflection from inter-sheet spacing); (4) Electron microscopy (unbranched fibrils, 7-13 nm diameter). Biological context: Functional amyloids are found in many organisms: E. coli curli fibrils (biofilm formation), spider silk (dragline strength), Pmel17/PMEL (melanin biosynthesis in melanosomes), peptide hormone storage (in secretory granules), and yeast prions (PSI⁺, URE3 — epigenetic switches). Functional amyloids are typically: tightly regulated, rapidly formed and disassembled, compartmentalized, and not cytotoxic. Option A ignores functional amyloids. Option C doesn't detect amyloid. Option B is irrelevant.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are long, unbranched polysaccharides found in the extracellular matrix. The most abundant GAG in the human body is:
options: Heparin, which is found exclusively in mast cell granules
Keratan sulfate, which is found only in the cornea

Hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan), a non-sulfated GAG composed of repeating disaccharide units of GlcUA-GlcNAc, that can be millions of daltons in size, occupies large hydrodynamic volumes, and serves as a lubricant in synovial fluid, a shock absorber in cartilage, and a scaffold for proteoglycan assembly in the ECM
Dermatan sulfate, which is the only GAG found in skin
questions.explanation: Hyaluronic acid (HA) is unique among GAGs: it is non-sulfated, not attached to a protein core (it is not a proteoglycan), and can reach enormous sizes (up to 10⁷ Da, or ~25,000 disaccharide repeats). Its repeating disaccharide is β-1,4-D-glucuronic acid (GlcUA) linked β-1,3 to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). HA's highly negative charge (one carboxylate per disaccharide) attracts water, creating a viscous, hydrated gel that occupies enormous hydrodynamic volumes (a single HA molecule can occupy the volume of a bacterium). HA serves as: a lubricant in synovial fluid (joints), a shock absorber in vitreous humor and cartilage, a scaffold for aggrecan proteoglycan aggregates (link protein + aggrecan monomers + HA backbone), and a regulator of cell migration during development and wound healing. HA is synthesized at the plasma membrane by hyaluronan synthases. Option A is one GAG but not the most abundant. Option B is too narrow. Option D is also too narrow.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Selenocysteine (Sec, the 21st amino acid) is incorporated into proteins during translation by a unique mechanism that involves:
options: A standard codon that normally encodes selenocysteine in all organisms
A separate ribosome that only translates selenoprotein mRNAs
Random insertion of selenium into any cysteine position after translation

The UGA codon (normally a stop codon) being recoded as selenocysteine when a specific mRNA secondary structure (SECIS element, selenocysteine insertion sequence) in the 3' UTR signals the translational machinery, along with specialized factors including selenocysteine-specific tRNA (tRNA^Sec), selenocysteine synthase, and elongation factor SelB/EFsec
questions.explanation: Selenocysteine (Sec) is genetically encoded by the UGA codon, which normally signals translation termination. The recoding of UGA from 'stop' to 'selenocysteine' requires: (1) A SECIS element (selenocysteine insertion sequence) — a stem-loop RNA structure in the 3' UTR of eukaryotic selenoprotein mRNAs (or immediately downstream of the UGA codon in prokaryotes); (2) A unique tRNA^Sec (anticodon UCA) that is initially charged with serine by seryl-tRNA synthetase, then the serine is enzymatically converted to selenocysteine while still on the tRNA; (3) A specialized elongation factor — SelB in bacteria or EFsec/SBP2 in eukaryotes — that recognizes the SECIS element and delivers the Sec-tRNA^Sec to the ribosome at UGA codons. There are ~25 selenoproteins in humans, including glutathione peroxidase, thioredoxin reductase, and iodothyronine deiodinases. Option A is wrong — UGA is normally a stop codon. Option C is wrong — Sec is co-translationally inserted. Option B is wrong — standard ribosomes are used.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is activated when misfolded proteins accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum. The three main ER stress sensors are:
options: p53, Rb, and Myc — tumor suppressor and oncogene proteins

IRE1, PERK, and ATF6 — transmembrane proteins that detect unfolded proteins in the ER lumen and activate signaling cascades to restore ER homeostasis by upregulating chaperones, inhibiting general translation, and promoting ERAD (ER-associated degradation)
Caspase-3, Caspase-9, and cytochrome c — apoptosis executioners
Toll-like receptors TLR4, TLR7, and TLR9 — innate immune sensors
