questions.explanation: The UPR maintains ER protein homeostasis through three parallel signaling branches: (1) IRE1 (inositol-requiring enzyme 1): an ER transmembrane kinase/endoribonuclease. When activated by unfolded proteins, IRE1 splices XBP1 mRNA (unconventional cytoplasmic splicing), producing spliced XBP1 (XBP1s) transcription factor that upregulates ER chaperones (BiP/GRP78), ERAD components, and lipid biosynthesis genes. (2) PERK (PKR-like ER kinase): phosphorylates eIF2α, globally inhibiting translation (reducing the protein load on the ER) while selectively upregulating ATF4 (which induces CHOP/GADD153 under prolonged stress, promoting apoptosis). (3) ATF6: a transcription factor that is cleaved by S1P/S2P proteases in the Golgi upon ER stress, releasing its cytoplasmic domain that translocates to the nucleus and upregulates ER chaperones and ERAD genes. If the UPR fails to restore homeostasis, apoptosis is triggered through CHOP and IRE1-JNK signaling. Option A describes cancer-related proteins. Option C describes apoptosis effectors. Option D describes innate immunity.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Keratin, the structural protein of hair, nails, and the outer layer of skin, derives its mechanical strength from:
options: Hydrogen bonds alone, which make keratin extremely sensitive to humidity
Glycosylation of surface residues that creates a rigid sugar coating
Ionic bonds between acidic and basic amino acids on the protein surface

Extensive disulfide bonds between cysteine residues in adjacent α-helical coiled-coil chains, creating a rigid cross-linked network — the high cysteine content (~7-20%) and the coiled-coil quaternary structure provide both flexibility and tensile strength
questions.explanation: Keratin's strength comes from a hierarchical structural organization: (1) Individual α-helices with a heptad repeat pattern (abcdefg) where positions a and d are hydrophobic. (2) Two α-helices wrap around each other to form a coiled-coil dimer (left-handed supercoil). (3) Dimers associate into protofilaments, which bundle into intermediate filaments (~10 nm diameter). (4) Extensive disulfide bonds between cysteine residues in adjacent chains create a rigid, covalently cross-linked network. Hard keratins (hair, nails, claws, horns, feathers) have high cysteine content (7-20%) and many disulfide bonds, making them hard and insoluble. Soft keratins (skin epidermis) have fewer disulfide bonds and are more flexible. Permanent waving of hair works by reducing disulfide bonds (thioglycolate), reshaping the hair, then re-oxidizing (hydrogen peroxide) to form new disulfide bonds in the new configuration. Option A ignores the critical disulfide bonds. Option C plays a minor role. Option B is not a feature of keratin.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Nucleosomes are the fundamental unit of chromatin structure. Each nucleosome consists of:
options: A single histone protein wrapped by DNA
A lipid core surrounded by a DNA shell
Four copies of histone H1 wrapped by RNA

An octamer of histone proteins (two copies each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4) around which approximately 147 base pairs of DNA are wound in 1.65 left-handed superhelical turns, with histone H1 serving as a linker histone that stabilizes higher-order chromatin structure
questions.explanation: The nucleosome core particle (solved at 2.8 Å resolution by Luger et al., 1997) consists of 147 bp of DNA wrapped in 1.65 left-handed superhelical turns around a histone octamer. The octamer contains two copies each of four core histones (H2A, H2B, H3, H4), arranged as an (H3-H4)₂ tetramer flanked by two H2A-H2B dimers. Histones are small, basic (lysine- and arginine-rich) proteins that interact with DNA primarily through electrostatic interactions and minor groove contacts. The 'beads on a string' structure (10 nm fiber) is further compacted by linker histone H1, which binds to the nucleosome entry/exit sites and ~20 bp of linker DNA, promoting formation of the 30 nm fiber and higher-order structures. Histone N-terminal tails protrude from the nucleosome and are sites of post-translational modifications (acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, ubiquitination) that regulate gene expression (the 'histone code'). Option A is incomplete. Option C is wrong. Option B is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The Edman degradation technique for protein sequencing involves:
options: Randomly breaking all peptide bonds simultaneously and analyzing the mixture
Cutting the protein with trypsin and sequencing all fragments simultaneously
Complete hydrolysis of the protein followed by amino acid analysis

Sequential removal and identification of one amino acid at a time from the N-terminus using phenylisothiocyanate (PITC), which reacts with the free α-amino group under mildly alkaline conditions, followed by acid cleavage of only the first peptide bond to release the PTH-amino acid derivative for identification
questions.explanation: Pehr Edman developed this sequential degradation method in 1950. The chemistry involves: (1) Coupling: PITC (phenylisothiocyanate, Edman's reagent) reacts with the free α-amino group of the N-terminal amino acid under mildly alkaline conditions (pH 8-9), forming a phenylthiocarbamoyl (PTC) derivative. (2) Cleavage: Under anhydrous acid conditions (trifluoroacetic acid), only the PTC-derivatized N-terminal residue is cleaved as an anilinothiazolinone (ATZ) derivative, leaving the remaining polypeptide intact with a new N-terminal residue. (3) Conversion: The ATZ derivative is converted to a stable phenylthiohydantoin (PTH) amino acid for identification by HPLC. (4) The cycle repeats for the next residue. Modern automated sequencers (Edman sequenators) can sequence ~50-60 residues before cumulative losses reduce yield. For longer proteins, the protein is first fragmented (trypsin, CNBr) and overlapping fragments are sequenced. Today, mass spectrometry has largely replaced Edman degradation. Option A describes random hydrolysis. Option C determines composition, not sequence. Option B uses MS approaches.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Mucins are heavily O-glycosylated proteins that form the gel-like mucus layer protecting epithelial surfaces. Their distinctive bottle-brush structure arises from:
options: Dense N-linked glycosylation on asparagine residues

Hundreds of short O-linked glycan chains (typically 1-20 sugars) attached to serine and threonine residues in tandem repeat domains rich in Pro, Thr, and Ser — the clustered O-glycans create a stiff, extended structure that holds water and provides physical and chemical protection against pathogens and acid in the GI tract
Complete lack of any carbohydrate modification
Attachment of lipid anchors to the protein backbone
questions.explanation: Mucins (MUC1-MUC22 in humans) are large glycoproteins (0.5-40 MDa) with a characteristic domain structure: a central mucin domain containing tandem repeats rich in serine, threonine, and proline. The Ser/Thr residues are heavily modified with O-linked glycans (GalNAc-type, initiated by GalNAc-transferases in the Golgi). A single mucin molecule can carry hundreds of O-glycan chains, creating a 'bottle-brush' or 'pipe-cleaner' appearance. The dense glycosylation: (1) extends the polypeptide into a rigid rod-like conformation; (2) attracts water through the hydrophilic sugar chains; (3) creates a viscous gel (mucus) that physically protects underlying epithelium; (4) presents a dense glycan shield that blocks pathogen adhesion; (5) in the stomach, protects against acid and pepsin digestion. Secreted mucins (MUC2, MUC5AC) form the gel layer. Membrane-tethered mucins (MUC1, MUC16/CA-125) form the glycocalyx. Option A is wrong — mucins are predominantly O-glycosylated. Option C is wrong. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The Sanger dideoxy chain termination method for DNA sequencing relies on:
options: Chemical cleavage of DNA at specific bases using hazardous reagents
Direct reading of the DNA sequence through a nanopore without any synthesis

Incorporation of fluorescently labeled dideoxyribonucleoside triphosphates (ddNTPs) during DNA synthesis — ddNTPs lack the 3'-OH group needed for the next phosphodiester bond, so their random incorporation terminates chain elongation, producing a nested set of fragments that reveal the sequence when separated by capillary electrophoresis
Hybridization of short oligonucleotides to the target DNA
questions.explanation: Frederick Sanger's method (1977 Nobel Prize) exploits DNA polymerase's requirement for a 3'-OH to extend a growing chain. The reaction contains: (1) a single-stranded DNA template; (2) a primer; (3) DNA polymerase; (4) normal dNTPs (dATP, dCTP, dGTP, dTTP); (5) a small proportion of fluorescently labeled ddNTPs (ddATP, ddCTP, ddGTP, ddTTP, each with a different fluorescent dye). The 2',3'-dideoxyribose in ddNTPs lacks the 3'-OH group, so when a ddNTP is incorporated instead of the corresponding dNTP, chain elongation terminates. Because ddNTP incorporation is random and competitive, the reaction produces fragments of every possible length, each terminated with a fluorescent ddNTP that identifies the last base. Capillary gel electrophoresis separates these fragments by size (single-nucleotide resolution), and a laser detector reads the fluorescent labels as fragments pass, generating a chromatogram (sequence trace). Option A describes the Maxam-Gilbert method. Option B describes nanopore sequencing. Option D describes microarray hybridization.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Phospholipases are enzymes that cleave specific bonds in phospholipids. Phospholipase A₂ (PLA₂) specifically cleaves:
options: The head group from the phospholipid, leaving diacylglycerol
Both fatty acid chains simultaneously, releasing glycerophosphocholine

The ester bond at the sn-2 position, releasing a fatty acid (often arachidonic acid, the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis) and lysophospholipid — this reaction is a key step in inflammatory signaling
The phosphodiester bond in DNA, not in phospholipids
questions.explanation: Phospholipases are classified by their cleavage specificity: PLA₁ cleaves the sn-1 ester bond (releasing the saturated fatty acid); PLA₂ cleaves the sn-2 ester bond (releasing the unsaturated fatty acid, often arachidonic acid); PLC cleaves the phosphodiester bond on the glycerol side (releasing diacylglycerol and the phospho-head group); PLD cleaves the phosphodiester bond on the head group side (releasing the head group and phosphatidic acid). PLA₂ is particularly important in inflammation: (1) it releases arachidonic acid (20:4 ω-6) from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids; (2) arachidonic acid is then metabolized by COX (→ prostaglandins, thromboxanes) and LOX (→ leukotrienes); (3) the lysophospholipid product can be further converted to platelet-activating factor (PAF). Glucocorticoids (cortisol, dexamethasone) inhibit PLA₂ via lipocortin/annexin A1, explaining their anti-inflammatory effect. Snake and bee venoms contain potent PLA₂ enzymes. Option A describes PLC. Option B does not occur. Option D confuses with nucleases.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about protein denaturation:
S1: Denaturation disrupts secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structure but does not break peptide bonds (primary structure is preserved).
S2: Heat denatures proteins by increasing kinetic energy to the point where non-covalent interactions (hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic interactions, van der Waals forces) are overcome.
S3: Extreme pH denatures proteins by altering the ionization states of charged amino acid side chains, disrupting salt bridges and hydrogen bonds.
S4: All denatured proteins can be refolded to their native state simply by removing the denaturing agent.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, F, T
T, F, T, F
F, T, T, T
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Denaturation unfolds the protein's 3D structure but preserves the covalent peptide bonds of the primary sequence. Disulfide bonds (covalent) may or may not be broken depending on conditions. S2 is TRUE: Thermal denaturation occurs because increasing temperature increases molecular kinetic energy. Above the melting temperature (Tm), the thermal energy exceeds the stabilizing energy of non-covalent interactions, and the protein unfolds. S3 is TRUE: Extreme pH changes the protonation state of ionizable groups (Asp, Glu, His, Lys, Arg, Cys, Tyr), disrupting salt bridges and hydrogen bonds that stabilize the fold. Very low pH protonates carboxylate groups (destroying Asp-/Glu- to Lys+/Arg+ salt bridges). Very high pH deprotonates ammonium groups. S4 is FALSE: While some small proteins (e.g., ribonuclease A) can refold spontaneously in vitro, many proteins aggregate irreversibly upon denaturation. Large, multi-domain proteins, membrane proteins, and proteins that require chaperones for initial folding often cannot refold spontaneously. Cooking an egg is irreversible denaturation.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
A researcher measures the activity of an enzyme at different pH values:

| pH  | Relative activity (%) |
|-----|-----------------------|
| 2.0 | 100                   |
| 3.0 | 75                    |
| 4.0 | 30                    |
| 5.0 | 10                    |
| 6.0 | 2                     |
| 7.0 | 0                     |
| 8.0 | 0                     |

This pH-activity profile is most consistent with which enzyme?
options: Trypsin, which has an optimal pH of 8.0
Alkaline phosphatase, which has optimal activity at pH 10
Lysozyme, which is most active at neutral pH

Pepsin, a gastric aspartyl protease with optimal activity at pH 2.0, consistent with the highly acidic environment of the stomach (pH 1.5-3.5) — the two catalytic aspartate residues require different protonation states at low pH for the acid-base catalytic mechanism
questions.explanation: The pH-activity profile shows maximum activity at pH 2.0 with sharp decline as pH increases, reaching zero by pH 7.0. This is characteristic of pepsin, the major gastric protease. Pepsin is an aspartyl protease with two catalytic aspartate residues (Asp32 and Asp215). At pH 2.0, one Asp is protonated (acts as general acid) and the other is deprotonated (acts as general base), enabling the catalytic mechanism. As pH rises above 3.0, both Asp residues become deprotonated and catalysis is impaired. Pepsin is also irreversibly denatured above pH 6.0. This extreme acid optimum makes pepsin perfectly adapted to the stomach environment (pH 1.5-3.5). Pepsin is synthesized as pepsinogen (zymogen) and activated by autocatalytic cleavage at low pH. Option A is wrong — trypsin has a basic pH optimum (~8). Option C is wrong — lysozyme works at ~pH 5-7. Option B is wrong — alkaline phosphatase is optimum at pH 9-10.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: AlphaFold (developed by DeepMind) has revolutionized protein structure prediction. Its significance is that:
options: It replaces the need for all experimental structural biology techniques

It uses deep learning neural networks trained on known experimental structures to predict the 3D structure of proteins from amino acid sequence alone with near-experimental accuracy (median GDT >90 for most proteins), solving a 50-year grand challenge in biology — though it currently has limitations with intrinsically disordered regions, large complexes, and the effects of post-translational modifications
It can only predict the structure of proteins that have already been experimentally determined
It predicts protein function but not structure
questions.explanation: AlphaFold2 (announced at CASP14, 2020) and AlphaFold3 represent a transformative advance in computational biology. The system uses multiple sequence alignments (evolutionary information) and pair representations as input to a novel 'Evoformer' architecture (attention-based neural network) that iteratively refines predicted inter-residue distances and angles, ultimately outputting 3D coordinates with confidence scores (pLDDT). At CASP14, AlphaFold2 achieved a median GDT-TS of 92.4, approaching experimental accuracy. The AlphaFold Protein Structure Database now contains predicted structures for >200 million proteins (essentially all known sequences). Limitations: (1) IDPs are assigned low confidence; (2) conformational changes and alternative states are not well predicted; (3) effects of PTMs, ligands, and mutations require additional methods; (4) protein-protein complexes (partially addressed by AlphaFold-Multimer). AlphaFold complements, not replaces, experimental methods. Option A overstates its capabilities. Option C is wrong — it predicts novel structures. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: The post-translational modification ubiquitination tags proteins for degradation by the 26S proteasome. The ubiquitination cascade involves:
options: A single enzyme that attaches ubiquitin to any lysine on any protein
A single protease that cleaves ubiquitin from all proteins simultaneously
Direct chemical modification without any enzymatic catalysis

A three-enzyme cascade: E1 (ubiquitin-activating enzyme, ~2 in humans) activates ubiquitin in an ATP-dependent reaction, E2 (ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme, ~40 in humans) receives ubiquitin from E1, and E3 (ubiquitin ligase, >600 in humans) provides substrate specificity by recognizing and binding the target protein while catalyzing ubiquitin transfer from E2 to a lysine residue on the substrate
questions.explanation: The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) is the major pathway for regulated protein degradation in eukaryotic cells. The cascade: (1) E1 activation: Ubiquitin is activated by E1 in an ATP-dependent reaction, forming a high-energy E1~ubiquitin thioester bond. Only 2 E1s exist in humans (UBA1, UBA6). (2) E2 conjugation: Ubiquitin is transferred from E1 to the active-site cysteine of E2, forming an E2~ubiquitin thioester. ~40 E2s provide some substrate selectivity. (3) E3 ligation: E3 ubiquitin ligases provide the critical substrate specificity. >600 E3s in humans recognize specific degradation signals (degrons) on target proteins. E3s catalyze ubiquitin transfer from E2 to a lysine residue on the substrate. Polyubiquitin chains (linked through Lys48 of ubiquitin) are the canonical signal for proteasomal degradation. The 26S proteasome (20S catalytic core + 19S regulatory cap) unfolds and degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. Option A oversimplifies. Option C is wrong. Option B describes deubiquitinases.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question: Transition state analogs are among the most potent enzyme inhibitors known. They are effective because:
options: They resemble the substrate and bind weakly to the active site

They mimic the geometry and charge distribution of the transition state, binding to the enzyme 10³ to 10⁶ times more tightly than the substrate itself — this is consistent with Pauling's proposal that enzymes achieve catalysis by preferentially stabilizing the transition state over the ground state substrate
They destroy the enzyme by covalent modification
They bind to allosteric sites rather than the active site
questions.explanation: Linus Pauling proposed in 1946 that enzymes are complementary to the transition state (TS) of the reaction, not to the substrate ground state. This means enzymes bind the TS more tightly than the substrate, thereby lowering the activation energy. Transition state analogs are stable molecules that mimic the TS geometry and charge distribution. Because they are complementary to the enzyme's optimized TS-binding site, they bind with extraordinary affinity — often 10³ to 10⁶ times tighter than the substrate (Kd in the picomolar to femtomolar range). Examples: (1) Proline racemase: the planar TS analog pyrrole-2-carboxylate binds 160× tighter than proline. (2) Purine nucleoside phosphorylase: the TS analog immucillin-H (Kd ~56 pM). (3) HIV protease: darunavir and other protease inhibitors incorporate tetrahedral TS mimics. (4) Abzymes (catalytic antibodies) are generated against TS analogs. Option A underestimates their potency. Option C describes irreversible inhibitors. Option D is wrong.
questions.topic: Structure and Function of Large Biological Molecules

questions.question:
Match the following enzyme regulation mechanisms with their descriptions:
(I) Competitive inhibition
(II) Uncompetitive inhibition
(III) Non-competitive inhibition
(IV) Allosteric activation

(P) Inhibitor binds only to the ES complex, decreasing both apparent Km and Vmax proportionally
(Q) Regulatory molecule binds to a site other than the active site, stabilizing the R-state and increasing enzyme activity
(R) Inhibitor structurally resembles the substrate and competes for the active site; increasing substrate concentration can overcome the inhibition
(S) Inhibitor binds to a site distinct from the active site on both free enzyme and ES complex, reducing Vmax without affecting Km
options: I-R, II-P, III-S, IV-Q
I-P, II-R, III-Q, IV-S
I-S, II-Q, III-R, IV-P
I-R, II-S, III-P, IV-Q
questions.explanation: Competitive inhibition (I-R): The inhibitor mimics the substrate and binds the active site. It raises apparent Km (reduced substrate affinity) but Vmax is unchanged at sufficiently high [S]. Classical examples include methotrexate competing with dihydrofolate for dihydrofolate reductase, and malonate competing with succinate for succinate dehydrogenase. Uncompetitive inhibition (II-P): The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to free enzyme. This decreases both apparent Km and Vmax by the same factor (1 + [I]/Ki'). Lithium inhibition of inositol monophosphatase is a clinical example. Non-competitive inhibition (III-S): The inhibitor binds both free enzyme and ES complex with equal affinity. Vmax decreases but Km remains unchanged because substrate binding is unaffected. Heavy metal ions often act as non-competitive inhibitors. Allosteric activation (IV-Q): Activators bind regulatory sites distinct from the active site, shifting the equilibrium toward the active R-state. ATP citrate lyase activation by insulin-stimulated dephosphorylation is an example. Therefore I-R, II-P, III-S, IV-Q, making Option A correct.
